column2: Elfrid Payton (right ankle) ruled out vs. GSW:

Justin Jackson getting the start Tuesday: De'Aaron Fox, Buddy Hield, Nemanja Bjelica and Willie Cauley-Stein are also starting. Jackson is getting the nod with Iman Shumpert resting, but he has limited upside and is just a desperation play in deep leagues.

Kelly Oubre (illness) active for Tuesday: If he's feeling up to it, the Wizards could rely on Oubre a ton in small-ball lineups because they are missing Dwight Howard (back) and Markieff Morris (concussion). The illness adds an element of risk, though.

Kevin Love to be re-evaluated in a few weeks: Love said he initially injured his toe during a preseason game against the Celtics, and with the Cavs opening the year up 0-6, there wasn't much incentive for him to keep pushing through the pain. The toe issue was so painful that it was uncomfortable for him to put any pressure on it, and he did undergo an MRI. He remains without an official timetable, but Adrian Wojnarowski reported on Monday that he could be out for more than a month. Owners should hold on until we get a more definitive timetable, but it's concerning that he has met with renowned foot surgeon Dr. Martin O'Malley. Larry Nance figures to be one of the primary beneficiaries while he's out.

Marquese Chriss (left ankle) is available: Coach Mike D'Antoni noted that Chriss is ready physically, but said he also looked rusty at practice. For that reason,  Isaiah Hartenstein will probably remain ahead of Chriss for now.

Nerlens Noel (ankle) is available Tuesday: Steven Adams (calf) is available too, and unless he has restrictions, Noel is likely looking at minutes in the teens. Noel has been terrific this season, but a healthy Adams severely caps his upside.

Steven Adams, Noel available to play Tuesday: Adams missed Sunday's game vs. the Suns with a minor calf issue, but he should be back in the starting lineup tonight with his usual minutes, which really hurts Noel. Feel free to get Adams active for a favorable matchup in Los Angeles.

No timetable for James Johnson, Dion Waiters: Both these guys have yet to make their regular-season debuts, and based on this quote from Spoelstra, it doesn't seem like either one is close. Kelly Olynyk and Justise Winslow will continue to man the four-spot while Johnson is out, and Rodney McGruder has been one of the biggest beneficiaries with both Waiters and Johnson on the sidelines. At this point, Johnson belongs on the waiver wire in most leagues.

Nurse says shorter stints for JV and Ibaka: Nurse said he doesn't have a preference on who will matchup with Joel Embiid, so Nurse will likely be going with whoever has the hot hand tonight. The timeshare situation at the five-spot in Toronto has been annoying for JV owners, and it's somewhat disheartening that he won't be drawing the start tonight against a more traditional center in Embiid.

Suns decline Dragan Bender's option: The option was for $5.9 million, so it would have been a major upset if the Suns actually picked it up. Bender has shown little to no progress in terms of development and will be labeled a bust until he proves otherwise. Bender has played a total of 11 minutes this season.

De'Aaron Fox (back) available to play Tuesday: Fox didn't seem too limited while going through his pregame routine, so it looks like he'll be fighting through the pain tonight. Just a note, available to play doesn't always mean 'will play,' and with this being the second leg of a back-to-back set, it wouldn't be surprising to see Fox minutes limited tonight. He's safe to fire up in season-long settings, but is a risky play in DFS.

Kawhi Leonard starting, Powell to the bench: The Raptors are bringing Kawhi along slowly since he barely played last season, so his fantasy owners should be aware of upcoming back-to-backs. Toronto's next one is right around the corner on Nov. 4 vs. the Lakers and Nov. 5 vs. the Jazz, but it's not a lock that he misses one of those.

Fred VanVleet (toe) out Tuesday vs. 76ers: This will be the fourth game in a row that FVV will be watching from the sidelines, which will translate to more minutes for Delon Wright and Lorenzo Brown. The Raptors take on the Suns on Friday, and for now, we'll be considering VanVleet questionable for that one.

Aron Baynes (hamstring) will play on Tuesday: Baynes will be returning to the lineup following a three-game absence, and he won't have any minutes restrictions for tonight's game. He could flirt with close to 20 minutes going up against Detroit's more traditional frontcourt, which could somewhat cut into Marcus Morris' minutes. Baynes is not a great target in fantasy hoops, though.

De'Aaron Fox (back) a game-time decision: Fox tweaked his back on a layup late in Monday's win, and with this being the second game of a back-to-back set, there's a real possibility that he won't be taking the floor tonight. The Kings are notorious for being late with the injury updates, so Fox will be an extremely risky play in DFS. If he's out, Yogi Ferrell and Frank Mason will see an uptick in minutes.
Jevon Carter recalled from the G-League: He might play if the game turns into a blowout, but he won't be on the floor in any meaningful way tonight.

Anthony Davis (elbow) questionable Wednesday: Head coach Alvin Gentry said he'll be making a decision on Davis following Wednesday morning's shootaround, so owners can expect to get another update tomorrow afternoon. AD could be headed for a game-time call, but if he's out again, it'll either be Jahlil Okafor or Julius Randle getting the start, with more shots falling to Nikola Mirotic, Jrue Holiday and E'Twaun Moore. Stay tuned.

Thibs wants Rose to play 26-28 mins a night: Rose has actually been surprisingly effective for the Wolves this season, posting averages of 14.8 points, 4.3 assists and just 1.0 turnover per game on 41.3% shooting from the field and 81.8% from the stripe in 28.3 minutes a night, which has been good enough for late-round value in 9-cat leagues. He won't be the difference maker on a championship team in fantasy hoops, but he's doing enough to warrant ownership in deep leagues.

Andrew Wiggins (quad) questionable Wednesday: Wiggins has spent the past three games on the sidelines and the Wolves haven't provided any updates as to how close he is. Tom Thibodeau implied over the past two games that Wiggins was close, and he appeared to be on track to play on Monday after getting through shootaround without issue, but the end result was another missed game. He'll likely be a game-time call, and if he's out again, Josh Okogie will again be worth a punt in DFS.

Rodions Kurucs (ankle) out Wednesday vs. DET: This will be his fifth straight game on the sidelines, and it's unclear exactly when we can expect him back. He probably won't be a major factor in the rotation while Rondae Hollis-Jefferson is healthy, so he's safe to leave on the waiver wire in all formats.

Moe Harkless (knee) out Tuesday vs. Houston: Head coach Terry Stotts said earlier today that he expected Harkless to be available for tonight's game, so it's not clear if he suffered a setback after shootaround. This will be the second straight game on the sidelines for Harkless, which will translate to more minutes for Evan Turner, Jake Layman and potentially, Zach Collins. Harkless belongs on the waiver wire in all formats.

Jae Crowder (ankle) probable for Wednesday: Crowder tweaked his right ankle late in Sunday's game, but it looks like he plans to power through it, given that he's being listed as probable. The Jazz need him with Derrick Favors dealing with knee issues, so there's a chance he could start on Wednesday night. Check back for another update following Wednesday morning's shootaround.

Derrick Favors (knee) questionable Wednesday: Favors sat out Sunday's game due to the sore knee, and it's concerning that his troublesome left knee is giving him issues this early in the year. We'll have a better idea on his status following Wendesday morning's shootaround, but if he's out again, Jae Crowder will be the primary beneficiary. Stay tuned.

Alec Burks (hand) questionable for Wednesday: Burks was cleared for Sunday's game, but didn't actually step foot on the court, and that could be the same scenario that plays out on Wednesday. Leave him on the wire.

Wilson Chandler (hamstring) out Tuesday: On Monday, Brett Brown said that Chandler wasn't 'that far off' from making his regular-season debut, so while he won't take the floor tonight, he does appear to be inching his way closer to his return. He's not worth stashing anywhere, but once he's back, Chandler could really hurt Dario Saric.

Kevin Knox goes through non-contact work: Knox is hopeful to get back to the court by early-November, but he remains without an official timetable and the Knicks aren't in any rush to get him back. While he's out, Damyean Dotson and Mario Hezonja will pick up the majority of his minutes, and both those guys are on the radar in deep leagues. Knox wasn't playing all that well prior to going down, so he's not necessarily worth holding if you don't have an IR-spot.
Chasson Randle inks deal with Washington: He'll help bring some depth to Washington's backcourt, but as the 14th man on this roster, we don't anticipate him making any noise in fantasy hoops.

James Johnson (hernia) listed as out Tuesday: Johnson has been sidelined since the start of the regular season, and we haven't received any updates on his practice availability over the past two days. Hopefully, he is moving in the right direction. We should have confirmation on his status later this evening.

Kelly Oubre (illness) a GTD on Tuesday: The 1-5 Wizards, who are in desperate need of win, have already ruled out Markieff Morris (concussion). If Oubre is also unable to play, they will have very little depth up front. Austin Rivers and Tomas Satoransky would likely see some time on the wing, shifting Otto Porter over to PF. Jeff Green will see plenty of playing time across the frontcourt and is worth consideration as a DFS dart throw.

Markieff Morris (concussion) out Tuesday: Morris has entered the NBA's concussion protocol, meaning he will have to be cleared by league doctors before being able to return to game action. Kelly Oubre (illness) will be a game-time decision on Tuesday, which means the Wizards frontline could be extremely thin on Tuesday night. Jeff Green and Jason Smith will likely log all the minutes they can handle.

Pistons will decline Ellenson's extension: Despite being a former No. 1 overall pick by the Pistons, this is not surprising. After two disappointing seasons to start his career, Ellenson has fallen out of the rotation completely in Detroit. He didn't make his season debut until the Pistons got blown out by the Celtics on Saturday.

Luc Mbah a Moute (sore left knee): Doc Rivers told reporters that he is hopeful Mbah a Moute will return Thursday in Philadelphia and said LMAM is 'right around the corner because he made the trip out.' Danilo Gallinari and Montrezl Harrell will continue to soak up extra minutes on Tuesday.

OG Anunoby (personal) out again Tuesday: We don't have details as to the reason, but Anunoby has been away from the team since Friday. Hopefully, all is well. Pascal Siakam has soaked up extra minutes with OG out. Kawhi Leonard (rest) will also return for the Raps on Tuesday night.

Fred VanVleet (turf toe) questionable Tuesday: VanVleet has missed each of the Raptors last three contests. However, he was able to get in a limited practice on Sunday, so appears to be headed in the right direction. If he is ruled out for Tuesday's game vs. Philly, Delon Wright will again serve as the primary backup PG behind Kyle Lowry.

Iman Shumpert (rest) ruled out Tuesday: Shumpert missed the majority of the 2017-18 season but has been healthy this year, appearing in six of the Kings first seven games (four starts). Sacramento will likely continue to rest him on back-to-backs going forward. Justin Jackson and Buddy Hield should see an uptick in playing time with Shump sidelined on Tuesday.

De'Aaron Fox (back) questionable for Tuesday: Per the Kings injury report, Fox strained his lower back when scoring on a layup late in the fourth quarter of Monday's victory in Miami. Fox has been playing very well this season, averaging 18.0 points (on 48.4 percent shooting(, 4.1 rebounds and 7.1 assists over his first seven games. Hopefully, this is only a minor ailment that doesn't sideline him. We can expect an update later this afternoon. If Fox is ruled out, Yogi Ferrell and Frank Mason would divvy up extended minutes at point guard.

Warriors plan to pick up Damian Jones' option: Jones is making around $1.5 million this season. His salary will jump to $2.3 million for the 2019-20 season. He's been solid for Golden State thus far, averaging 6.0 points, 2.4 rebounds, and 1.4 blocks, while shooting a league-high 77.8 percent from the floor.

Daniel Theis (foot) to miss at least 2 weeks: Theis told reported he feels optimistic about his recovery: 'This one is going to be way shorter than the knee injury (that ended his rookie season).' Even when fully healthy, Theis has limited fantasy value. He should be left on waivers.

Harkless (left knee) expected to play Tuesday: Harkless was forced out of Saturday's game due to knee pain and was ruled out of Monday's win over the Pacers. However, it seems to be only a minor issue, as he'll be back in the lineup on Tuesday. Nonetheless, Harkless is averaging just 3.8 points in 17.6 minutes per game this season. He should be left on waivers.
Mavs assign Ray Spalding to G League: Spalding, the 56th overall pick in the 2018 NBA draft, will spend most of this season in the G-League. He is not on the fantasy radar.

Elie Okobo impressing Suns coaching staff: After starting point guard Isaiah Canaan left early with a sprained left ankle in the first quarter, Okobo stepped in and stepped up. He logged a career-high 31 minutes and tallied 18 points, five rebounds, seven assists, three 3-pointers and just three turnovers. 'He played with confidence, he played with a presence. He played like, I belong here,' said Kokosov. Canaan said his ankle is 'fine,' but Okobo is a big part of the Suns future while Canaan is not. Okobo's fantasy stock is on the rise.

Isaiah Canaan (ankle) says he is 'fine': Canaan tweaked the ankle in the first quarter of Sunday loss. That's the same ankle he inuured badly last season. However, he said he could've returned to Sunday's game, but the trainers didnt want to risk turning something minor into something major. 'I was like, ah naw, not again, but it was fine,' Canaan said. Nonetheless, Elie Okobo stepped in for Canaan and poured in 18 points. Okobo looks like he's the point guard to own in Phoenix.

Jabari Parker plays well in loss to GSW: Parker's rolling, for the most part, and is averaging 16.6 points, 6.2 rebounds, 3.0 assists, 0.8 steals, 0.8 blocks and 1.4 3-pointers over his last five games. He'd hit five 3-pointers over his previous two games and hasn't shot it poorly from the line this season, so the negatives he provided tonight look like a fluke. He's fitting in nicely with the Bulls this season.

Wendell Carter Jr. scores 18 points in loss: He's slowly getting more comfortable and his production has been trending up for a week now. This was his only game without a blocked shot, he's averaging over 3.0 assists per 36 minutes and is locked in as the starter for the entire season. Hopefully you hung onto him after his slow start, but patience is needed when you're dealing with rookies.

Antonio Blakeney scores career-high 21 points: This game was over in the first quarter, so Blakeney cleaned up in garbage time with 14 points in the fourth quarter alone. He can put up points in a hurry, but we can't recommend him until he starts getting consistent run. Don't be surprised if coach Fred Hoiberg lets him loose again next game.

Quinn Cook scores season-high 16 points: He also pulled down two rebounds with one assist and one triple in 17 minutes. 11 of his points came in garbage time, so we can't read too much into this line. He'll be the third-string PG once Shaun Livingston gets healthy.
Tim Frazier plays 20 minutes, scores 5 points: Frazier saw a season-high 20 minutes with Elfrid Payton out. He's worth a look in deeper leagues for as long as Payton is out of the lineup.

Cheick Diallo goes for 8/5 in 14 minutes: Diallo saw an uptick in minutes with Anthony Davis out and produced in limited minutes. He's buried on the depth chart, but posts solid per-minute numbers. Just something to file away.

Klay Thompson scores 52 points, hits 14 treys: Remember that buy-low window we talked about when Thompson started the season shooting 5-of-36 from deep, well it just slammed shut. Thompson's 52 points is the highest scoring game of the season with Curry (51) and Blake Griffin (50) right behind. Thompson added five rebounds and one steal, and he did all of his damage in 27 minutes because of the lopsided score. That's the Klay fantasy owners know and love.

E'Twuan Moore scores 18 points in 38 minutes: Moore isn't the most productive Pelican but he still benefits from them playing super fast. He's scored in double-digits in five of six games and is worth owning in 12-team leagues.

Ian Clark plays just six minutes on Monday: Clark was originally slated to start, but found himself back in his usual role after a late change. Frank Jackson has played well in two-straight games and might be passing Clark in the rotation. Clark isn't worth owning in any format after playing just six minutes with three rotation players out.

Frank Jackson plays career-high 26 minutes: Jackson saw a huge bump in minutes with Elfrid Payton and Darius Miller out and even played ahead of Ian Clark. Jackson looks to be emerging as an option off the bench for the Pelicans, making him an interesting flier in deep-leagues.

Wesley Matthews scores eight points Monday: He'd scored in double digits in all six of his games coming in and had ripped off four straight games of at least 20 points, so he was due for a letdown. He's been a very pleasant surprise up to this point of the season, so hopefully tonight wasn't a sign of things to come. He should bounce back on Wednesday against the Lakers.

Jahlil Okafor starts, scores 9 in 18 minutes: Okafor got the start at center with Anthony Davis out. Julius Randle started the previous game, with Okafor coming off the bench. He's only worth a look while Davis is out.

Luka Doncic (back) scores career-high 31: Well then, so much for the back injury. The comparison between Doncic and Trae Young will likely last for years, and it's already been a fun ride in their rookie seasons. Young turned heads with his 35 points and 11 assists on Oct. 21, but Doncic returned serve with tonight's gem. For the record, Doncic is averaging 18.7 points, 6.2 rebounds, 4.0 assists, 0.8 steals and 2.5 3-pointers on 43 percent shooting in six games. And Trae is averaging 19.8 points, 3.4 rebounds, 6.8 assists, 0.8 steals and 2.4 3-pointers on 39 percent shooting through five games. Hopefully, Doncic's back problem is a thing of the past after this one. The best stat of the night is that Doncic became the third youngest NBA player to have at least 30 points and eight boards in a game. The other two are LeBron James and Kevin Durant. Wow.
Solomon Hill scores 4 points in start: Hill got the start with two starters and Darius Miller missing for the Pelicans. He didn't produce much and isn't on the fantasy radar.

Thon Maker scores season-high 11 points: Coach Mike Budenholzer said Maker would get an opportunity with Giannis Antetokounmpo (concussion) out and kept his word. Instead of deploying Maker at center, he was used as a stretch four tonight, an interesting wrinkle to consider in the future if Giannis misses more time. For now, Maker is just a stash in dynasty formats, but deep-league owners can give him a look if we get bad news on the Greek Freak.

Julius Randle drops 24/8/6 off the bench: Randle returned to the second unit after starting the Pelicans last game. They were still without Anthony Davis, but opted for Jahlil Okafor running with the starters in this one. Randle's per-minute production has been superb thus far and he still has value even has a sixth man.

Eric Bledsoe scores 17 points in 26 minutes: He shook off a slow start tonight which was a relief to his fantasy owners, as he scored a combined 12 points in his previous two games. He finished 7-of-12 from the field, hit his only free throw and turned the ball over three times. The Bucks are 7-0 and are off to their best start in franchise history, setting up an epic showdown against Boston on Thursday. Bledsoe will have plenty of motivation for this one because of his history with Terry Rozier.

Harrison Barnes looks better on Monday: This was Barnes third game of the season and the first where he looked like his old self. This was easily his best game of the three and while it's encouraging, it could still take him another few games to round into form. But if you need to get him into your lineup, it appears that he might be ready to get it going.

Jrue Holiday nears triple-double w/ 16/8/9: Holiday has been exceptional of late for the fast-paced Pelicans. He's contributing across the board and even has some room for improvement. Holiday looks to be over his slow start and should be a steady option moving forward.

Ersan Ilyasova scores 19 in start vs. TOR: Considering he averaged 11.7 points, 5.9 rebounds, 1.2 assists, 0.9 steals and 1.4 triples as a starter last season, anyone who streamed him in season-long leagues or deployed him in DFS had themselves a great night. The Bucks are off until Thursday's showdown with the Celtics, so fantasy owners can wait for an update on Giannis before picking up Ersanity.

Nikola Mirotic double-doubles with 17 and 10: Mirotic continued his monster season in this one, notching his third double-double of the season. He's averaging nearly 20/10 with a handful of triples. Mirotic is enjoying life in the ultra fast-paced Pelicans lineup and looks like a draft day steal.

Delon Wright (groin) plays 13 minutes: Even with Fred VanVleet (toe) out, the Raptors eased Wright back into action tonight. His minutes could be on the rise soon, but Wright is more of a deep-league asset because Danny Green is having a terrific season.

Norman Powell scores eight points: He had seven points with five rebounds and one 3-pointer in his last start for Kawhi, so he's going to be even harder to trust the next time Kawhi sits. Powell belongs on the waiver wire.

Trey Lyles scores season-high 17 points: Lyles had his best game of the season on Monday. He's been playing most back-up four, but does see some time at the three. With Will Barton out, he'll continue to see playing time, making him an option in deeper leagues.

Josh Okogie scores 17 in start for Wiggins: That makes three straight missed games for Wiggins, and three solid games from Okogie in his last four. The 17 points were a season high, as were the 30 minutes, but Wiggins was close to playing tonight. Once he's back from his quad injury, Okogie should take a backseat to Wiggins and Derrick Rose. But given Rose's injury history, it could just take an injury to Rose to thrust Okogie back into the spotlight. Just keep an eye on him, or feel free to use him in DFS if Wiggins is going to miss any more games.

Pascal Siakam breaks out w/ 22 points: He has now started six out of seven games for the Raptors, but didn't make much noise until his last two games. In that span, he's averaging 16.0 points, 7.5 rebounds, 2.5 assists and 2.5 steals in 35.0 minutes. He's benefitted from OG Anunoby missing two games for personal reasons and Kawhi Leonard resting tonight, but Siakam is trending up as a pickup in standard leagues for his multi-category upside.

Jimmy Butler bounces back with season-high 32: JB hit just 2-of-11 shots for four points in 24 minutes on Friday, when he was dealing with an illness, but looked like a different guy tonight. We still have no idea how things will end up between Butler and the Wolves, but as long as he's there and playing, he should be in your lineup. He hit the game-sealing dagger against the Lakers tonight, as Jimmy is apt to do.

Malik Beasley plays season-high 31 minutes: Beasley played a critical role in the Nuggets win and played much more than starter Torrey Craig. With Will Barton out for the foreseeable future, Beasley has a chance to grab hold of some playing time. He's not worth an add just yet, but keep an eye on him in deeper leagues.

Karl-Anthony Towns has breakout game vs. LA: To be fair, the steal and four blocks tied season highs, but none the less, this was the first WOW line of KAT's young season. He managed to do it with Jimmy Butler in the lineup (and going off), and we can only hope that this is start of a big run for KAT. He hasn't really been bad this season, but for a guy who went Top 5 in almost every fantasy league, he's been a little quiet for most of his owner's liking. He does have a tough test on Halloween night though, as the Timberwolves will visit Rudy Gobert and the defensive-minded Jazz.

Serge Ibaka goes off for 30 points vs. MIL: He got off to a blistering start with 13 points in the first quarter, finishing 12-of-21 from the field and 4-of-4 from the line. He was one point shy of his career-high, taking on an expanded role on offense with Kawhi Leonard resting. Even though he's basically rotating in and out of the starting lineup with Jonas Valanciunas, Ibaka does look rejuvenated this season and is flirting with mid-round value. Expect him to come off the bench on Tuesday with Joel Embiid up next.

Josh Hart scores 5 off bench in 24 minutes: Owners of Hart and Lonzo Ball are not feeling the return of Ingram and Rajon Rondo right now, but patience is in order here. Hart's simply too good to keep off the floor for the Lakers, but he could be in for a quiet week or two as Luke Walton tries to figure out the best way to manage his stable of wings going forward.

Paul Millsap scores season-high 18 in win: Millsap has been inconsistent in the points column, but has been a steady contributor in the rebounding department. His contributions in the defensive area of the game is a big reason why he's still a valuable asset. Millsap won't be posting nightly double-doubles like he once did, but he's still very helpful.

Gary Harris drops 23/6/6 in Monday's win: Harris' two steals came in crucial late possessions and effectively sealed the win for the Nuggets. He's an incredibly important player on both ends and has picked up some action without Will Barton. Harris is a very steady fantasy contributor.

Lonzo Ball awful in loss to Wolves: He didn't play well and wasn't really even involved in the proceedings, while Rajon Rondo came off the bench for 13 points, six boards, eight assists and a 3-pointer on 6-of-9 shooting. Ball just got the job over Rondo while Rondo was out on suspension, but this wasn't a great showing, and his minutes have been dropping. Yeah, Ball's starting, but Rondo's getting the minutes right now, at least until Ball starts producing with the first unit. Just hang in there as the Lakers and Ball work through some growing pains.

Nikola Jokic nears triple-double w/ 12/9/10: Jokic was one rebound away from his second triple-double of the season. He played more of a facilitator role tonight, only attempting eight shots and racking up 10 assists. We didn't get to see him go up against Anthony Davis, but Jokic still showed why he's a top-ten fantasy player.

Jamal Murray swipes career-high 5 steals: Murray was active on the defensive end in this one, registering five steals and one block. He has yet to catch fire from deep, but is still finding ways to produce. The leg soreness appears to be a thing of the pass, setting up Murray to play a season-high 39 minutes. The minutes and shots are their for him, he just needs to get in a groove.

Welcome back: Ingram scores 24 in return: His four-game suspension is over and Ingram celebrated with season highs in points, rebounds, assists, blocks, 3-pointers, field goal attempts, shots made and free throws made. He's going to be playing a lot of shooting guard as long as LeBron James, Kyle Kuzma and JaVale McGee are all starting for the Lakers, but he can handle it.

Tim Hardaway Jr. scores 25 points vs. Nets: He took an elbow to the face and went back to the locker room in the second quarter, but later returned for the second half and obviously fared well. He matched his career-high in assists with eight and added five rebounds, one steal and three triples in 35 minutes. THJ will continue to run more offense if Frank Ntilikina keeps starting at point guard, so his fantasy arrow is pointing up. Hopefully they don't mess with his minutes like they're doing with Enes Kanter.

LeBron James' monster line not enough vs. MIN: He had a big game, but it wasn't enough to keep his Lakers from dropping to 2-5 on the season. LeBron's going to have to carry a heavy load this season to keep the Lakers afloat, but if they ever fall out of the playoff hunt, he' going to be a serious shutdown candidate. Hopefully, he'll play well enough not to let that happen.

Enes Kanter double-doubles off bench: He's not happy about coming off the bench and made that known, but coach David Fizdale said Kanter responded with a great practice over the weekend and it obviously carried over into this game. Kanter may have some ups and downs with the Knicks trying to get young guys like Mitchell Robinson and Noah Vonleh more involved, but he only needs minutes in the mid-20s to return mid-round value.

Kyle Kuzma starts, scores 19 points in loss: This wasn't his best game of the season, by far, but he was effective and got to keep his starting job, while Josh Hart was sent back to the bench with the return of Brandon Ingram. While the Lakers lineup is still a bit fluid, Kuzma has played well enough to command a starting job until further notice.

Emmanuel Mudiay plays two minutes: Coach David Fizdale believes Mudiay is 'the best passer' on the Knicks and he may get some starts down the road with the franchise in player-evaluation mode (tanking), but he's not someone to consider in fantasy leagues.

Frank Ntilikina scores 16 points vs. Nets: Not only was he good offensively, but he also shut down a red-hot Caris LeVert and held him to four points on 11 shots. Ntilikina started at point guard again and was aggressive early, something that coach David Fizdale keeps encouraging. He had a career-high 17 points with one rebound, two assists, one steal and three 3-pointers in 26 minutes in his previous start vs. the Warriors, so PG-needy owners should consider grabbing him now if you're OK with his volatile FG%.

Josh Richardson scores career-high 31 in loss: The zero dimes were weird, but he more than made up with it with the steals, blocks and 3-pointers, not too mention the points. He might have been on some benches with the Heat playing just three times this week, but hopefully yours wasn't one of them. J-Rich has been alternating good games with mediocre ones lately, but hopefully this is the start of a trend in the right direction. He's on track to have a big season.

Mitchell Robinson scores 11 points Monday: He had three fouls and played just 15 minutes, but he had a couple head-turning plays including a ridiculous display of athleticism on a steal that led to a breakaway dunk (link below). Knicks coach David Fizdale has already shown a willingness to ride his young guys with his team off to a 2-5 start, so it might not be long before Robinson becomes relevant in standard leagues for his blocks upside.

Whiteside goes ballistic with 16-24-5 line: He was one board shy of tying his career high, but easily set a season high with the boards tonight. His scoring and production is usually pretty touch and go, but he's hit double digits in rebounds in all five games this season, and has racked up 11 blocks over his last two games. Whiteside and Willie Cauley-Stein put on a show against each other tonight, but the Kings got the last laugh.

Rodney McGruder cools off in loss to Kings: McGruder had scored between 14 and 20 points in each of his last four games, and has been filling up the stat sheet since day one. This was his first game without either a block or a steal, but at least he kept his 3-point streak alive at six games this season. He's been picked up in almost all fantasy leagues and while this was a terrible way to start out Week 3, he should bounce back against the Hornets on Tuesday.

Spencer Dinwiddie scores 17 points vs. NYK: He was 6-of-10 from the field and 3-of-3 from the line with one turnover. Even with D'Angelo Russell and Caris LeVert off to a hot start, Dinwiddie is still getting minutes in the mid-20s consistently and will do just enough to warrant ownership in standard leagues.

Marvin Bagley plays just 17 minutes in win: Nemanja Bjelica, Willie Cauley-Stein, De'Aaron Fox and Buddy Hield were all on fire tonight, and have been playing well for most of the season, leaving Bagley on the bench to pick up scrap minutes where he can find them. It also doesn't help that the Kings have somehow won four of their last five games and three straight, making them a surprising 4-3 on the season. Until Bjelica cools down, it's going to be slow rolling with Bagley. Cut him if you must, but we recommend keeping him stashed until it's his time to shine for the Kings.

Trae Young nears double-double w/11 & 8 dimes: Young couldn't get his shots to fall from deep in this one, but still dished out eight assists. His usage rate remains high on the fast-paced Hawks, making him a solid fantasy option, even though he's inefficient. Don't let the bad nights get you down.

Buddy Hield has big night in another Kings W: The points and block also tied season highs, and Hield is on cruise control right now. Hopefully you have him in your lineup for all four games this week. Maybe he'll take a hit once Bogdan Bogdanovic returns from his knee injury, but Hield's playing well enough that it may not matter.

Vince Carter scores 4 points in 20 minutes: Carter is still starting in a small-ball four role for the Hawks, but is helping them more outside of the stat sheet. The veteran is only a punt play in DFS.
Omari Spellman scores 11, grabs 6 boards: Spellman is seeing playing time with John Collins still out with an injury. The rookie is a deep-league streamer for now.

Caris LeVert posts first dud of the season: Credit to Frank Ntilikina for playing some impressive defense on one of the hottest players in the East. Entering tonight's game, LeVert was one of nine players averaging 20+ points, 4+ rebounds and 4+ assists while shooting over 50 percent from the field, so his fantasy owners should cut him some slack. He salvaged his night with five assists, two steals and two rebounds, and he'll look to bounce back vs. the Pistons on Wednesday.

Alex Len plays only 15 minutes on Monday: Len has seen his minutes take a big hit with the return of Dewayne Dedmon. He still got the start against the Sixers, but that might not last for much longer. Len can't be counted on right now.

Iman Shumpert quiet in another start: He was starting to catch fire before missing a game with a hip injury, but his last two outings have been nothing to write home about. If you picked him up for his four-game week and the hopes of steals, blocks and 3-pointers, the good news is that he still has three games to proves his worth. It's possible that his two big games before his injury were just a fluke, but if he's going to prove otherwise, we hope he does so in a hurry. It's also worth noting that the other four Kings starters all had one of their best games of the season on Monday, meaning Shump was the odd man out on this night.

Willie Cauley-Stein blows up for huge line: Those were season highs in points and boards, and were in the ballpark of his career highs, as well. WCS has quietly double-doubled in his last three games, has scored in double digits in all seven of his games this season, and managed to pick up his first block since opening night on Monday. He's getting hot, and not coincidentally, the Kings have now won four of their last five games and three straight.

Victor Oladipo scores 21 points in loss: He hit his only free throw and finished 9-of-24 from the field. Oladipo is on pace for a career-high in usage rate (30.2) and has now scored 20+ points in each of his last six games since his quiet opener. He did have a collision with Jusuf Nurkic and took a shoulder to his chin, and while he looked a bit dazed initially, he seemed fine after a couple minutes.

Taurean Prince struggles, makes only one FG: Prince had been really good up until this one, but the defense of Robert Covington and the Sixers got the best of him. He's a huge part of the Hawks offense, but might lose some 4th quarter time in blowouts like this one. There's no reason to be worried, though, as Prince is well on his way to crushing his draft day position.

Nemanja Bjelica stays hot in win over Heat: It's becoming a broken record around here, but Bjelica continues to produce, while Marvin Bagley played just 17 minutes tonight. Until Bjelica's minutes start trending in the wrong direction, he should be owned in all fantasy leagues until further notice. Over his last five, he's averaging 15.6 points, 7.0 rebounds, 4.0 assists, 1.6 steals, 1.2 blocks and 2.6 3-pointers on 57 percent shooting with just 1.4 turnovers per game. If you picked him up early, he's already been a game changer for you in fantasy.

Darren Collison scores 17 w/ six assists: He also played a season-high 36 minutes even with Tyreke Evans back from his suspension, hitting 8-of-14 shots and finishing without a turnover. This was his second strong game in a row after a painfully slow start, so optimistic owners will be hoping that he has returned to his mid-round ways like he showcased last season.

Kent Bazemore scores 18 points on Monday: Bazemore contributed across the stat sheet in Monday's loss. He's been inconsistent, but still provides a source of steals and threes that makes him attractive in deeper leagues.

J.J. Redick ties career-high with 8 rebounds: Redick wasn't making a lot of his shots, but still found a way to contribute. He's had 3+ assists in four of the team's seven games now and matched a career-high with eight rebounds. Redick will be a great source of triples moving forward, as usual.

Mike Muscala hits 4 triples, scores 14 points: The 19 minutes were good for a season-high for Muscala and he earned them, knocking down a season-high four triples. The Sixers brought Moose in to help the bench and replicate the late-season production from Ersan Ilyasova. More nights like this will have him approaching the fantasy radar.

Tyreke Evans struggles in return: He was a -22 during his time on the floor and the entire second unit didn't show up for Indiana -- Portland's bench outscored Indiana 54-15. Evans picked the wrong time to miss practice, as Darren Collison has found his rhythm again and might be closing more games over Evans going forward. He'll try to get back on track in a favorable matchup vs. the Knicks on Wednesday.

Dario Saric's early-season struggles continue: Saric has been struggling and had his worst night of the season on Monday. Even though the shots aren't falling, he hasn't been lacking the confidence to attempt them. The Homie has also been active on the glass every night. The coaches don't seem worried, so you shouldn't be either. His 3-point percentage increased every month last season, which means it's not time to give up.

Myles Turner scores 10 points vs. Blazers: He was 5-of-12 from the field, but his blocks made up for the quiet night on the offensive end. The good news is that Turner logged seven minutes next to Domantas Sabonis, but the bad news is that that lineup got shredded -- they had a -33.8 net rating. Unless that combo is used more often, Turner's floor won't be as high on the nights when Sabonis has the hot hand.

Markelle Fultz scores career-high 16 points: Fultz took a career-high 16 shots and made a career-high 7 of them. He wasn't particularly aggressive in the first half, but showed a lot more fire in the second half. It's clear that Fultz struggles when playing with Ben Simmons (or T.J. McConnell), which is partly why he was more assertive in the second half and something the Sixers will need to figure out. The seven assists matched a season-high, as well as the one triple made. Fultz is maddeningly inconsistent, but still has obvious upside.

Al-Farouq Aminu double-doubles vs. IND: That's his second double-double of the season and he might have a few more minutes coming his way with Moe Harkless (knee) on the shelf again. He's not loaded with upside by any means and was averaging 7.4 points, 8.8 rebounds, 0.8 steals and 1.0 triples entering tonight's game on 34.3% shooting, but he might have some sneaky value this week with the Blazers playing four more times.

Caleb Swanigan double-doubles vs. Pacers: He played three minutes on the season entering tonight's game, so this truly came out of nowhere. The Pacers used some traditional lineups with Myles Turner getting run next to Domantas Sabonis, so Portland was able to play four bigs. Swanigan gave coach Terry Stotts something to think about tonight, but we'll need to see it again before recommending him outside of very deep leagues.

Joel Embiid scores season-low 10 points: Embiid attempted a season-low nine shots, which was a by-product of the Hawks doubling him almost every time he touched the ball. Tonight also snapped his six game double-double streak to open the season. The Sixers were up big in the fourth, which led to most of the Sixers rotation players sitting because it's the first night of a back-to-back set (related: there's been no talk of JoJo sitting tomorrow). Still, Embiid posted six assists and will be an elite fantasy option whenever he plays, even if he has an off night from the field.

Zach Collins stays hot w/ 17 points in win: Collins also hit both of his free throws, adding three rebounds, three assists, one block and one triple in 27 minutes. He took advantage of some early foul trouble by Jusuf Nurkic (two in the first couple minutes), and finished with a +22 during his time on the court. Collins continues to make a case for more playing time and already has mid-round value in category leagues despite coming off the bench, so he has to be owned right now with four more games on the schedule for Portland this week.

Ben Simmons posts 21/12/9 in just 27 minutes: Simmons went off in the third quarter, scoring 15 of his season-high 21 in that frame. He also rebounded from his season-low assist total last time out, dishing nine assists tonight. Simmons has been inconsistent from the free throw line, shooting just 56% on the season, but went 5-of-5 tonight. We know he's going to post a near triple-double every night, but if he can get his FT% above 70%, he'll be even more valuable.

Jusuf Nurkic plays just 18 minutes vs. IND: This was his second dud in a row after scoring five points vs. the Heat on Saturday. Nurkic got a quick hook  in the first quarter with a pair of fouls, and then he lost minutes to a red-hot Zach Collins off the bench (17 points in 27 minutes). Collins is becoming more and more of a threat to Nurkic, but his owners just have to hope that he can turn things around. Luckily, Portland plays four more times this week.

Update: Ian Clark off the bench: Coach Alvin Gentry said Clark was going to start for Elfrid Payton (ankle), but changed his mind before tip-off. Instead, Solomon Hill will entering the starting lineup.
Davis Bertans will come off the bench: It's becoming obvious that San Antonio's lineups are going to be fluid going forward. Dante Cunningham will start but he has no fantasy value.

Delon Wright (groin) is active Monday: He's had this injury for a while and the Raptors may monitor his minutes. Even with Fred VanVleet (toe) out, Wright is a shaky play until he proves he's 100 percent.

Fred VanVleet (turf toe) ruled out Monday: The Raptors waited until five minutes before tip-off to rule FVV out, and they also changed their starting lineup three times in the span of an hour. Delon Wright is active tonight and will handle the backup PG duties as long as he's healthy.

Julius Randle will come off the bench Monday: Randle got the start on Saturday with Anthony Davis (elbow) unavailable, but head coach Alvin Gentry will be going with a more traditional lineup today, running Jahlil Okafor at center. Randle should still see ample minutes with Davis watching from the sidelines, and he's actually been better as a reserve this season, so this isn't necessarily a bad thing.

Ian Clark starting for Elfrid Payton (ankle): Clark will be in there to space the floor but Jrue Holiday is going to run the show on offense. Clark is more of a deep-league streamer with some boom-or-bust appeal.

Okafor starting for Anthony Davis (elbow): The Pelicans are wanting some size for the matchup vs. Nikola Jokic, so Julius Randle will go back to his bench role. You would have to be desperate to pick up Okafor, especially since Davis is day-to-day.
Luka Doncic (sore back) will play Monday: Doncic will be watched closely, so DFS players should keep that in mind. We'll have an update on how he fares after the game.

Livingston (foot) expects to miss a few games: Livingston tweaked his foot during the Dubs' final preseason game, and unfortunately, it's become a nagging issue. While he doesn't think it's all that serious, he could get another MRI, and it sounds like he'll be taking the next handful of games off. Quinn Cook will serve as Stephen Curry's primary backup while Livingston is out.

Kyle Kuzma listed in the starting lineup Mon: Brandon Ingram is back from his four-game suspension, but it looks like he'll be starting at the two with Josh Hart moving back to the second unit. Joining Kuzma and Ingram in the starting five will be Lonzo Ball, LeBron James and JaVale McGee.

Josh Hart will come off the bench: The Lakers will start Brandon Ingram at shooting guard with Kyle Kuzma at power forward, but we still like Hart's chances of playing nearly 30 minutes. He's simply playing too well not to. His fantasy owners shouldn't panic.

Carlisle expects Luka Doncic to play: Dallas will monitor him up until tip-off, but barring a setback, he will be out there in his usual role. This makes him risky in DFS, but season-long owners can throw him into lineups.

Update: Andrew Wiggins (quad) out Monday: Wiggins was able to get through shootaround without issue, so maybe he tweaked something while going through his pregame routine. Unfortunately, he'll miss his third game in a row tonight, which will allow Josh Okogie to get another start, but he's been hit-or-miss with the starting unit. For now, we'll be considering Wiggins questionable for Wednesday's game against the Jazz.

Thon Maker to see some action Monday: Maker is the third center on the depth chart behind Brook Lopez and John Henson, but coach Mike Budenholzer said Maker may get an opportunity with Giannis Antetokounmpo (concussion) out. You still can't trust him in almost any fantasy league, though.

Anfernee Simons will be available to play Mon: Simons hasn't been able to get into the rotation this season, but that could change tonight with Moe Harkless (knee) watching from the sidelines. We don't expect him to get enough minutes to make an impact in fantasy hoops, though.

Norman Powell starting for Kawhi Leonard: Leonard will be back on Tuesday to take on the 76ers, so Powell is just a desperation streamer or a punt option in DFS. He wasn't effective in his last spot-start, scoring seven points with five rebounds and one 3-pointer.
Michael Beasley (personal) ruled out Monday: He's not a part of the rotation anyway, so his playing status is irrelevant in fantasy hoops.
Andre Iguodala (calf) available to play: Iguodala will be available, but the Dubs may monitor his minutes tonight with it being the second game of a back-to-back set. He's not worth owning anywhere.

Tyreke Evans will play Monday vs. Portland: Evans was given a one-game suspension for showing up late to a recent practice, but he's done his time and both sides look ready to move on. Feel free to get him active for an uptempo matchup against Portland.

Andrew Wiggins (quad) on track to play Monday: Head coach Tom Thibodeau said that Wiggins got through shootaround without any issues, so barring a setback during his pregame routine, he'll be back in action tonight following a two-game stint on the sidelines. With Wiggins back, Josh Okogie will return to the second unit, and he'll lose most his value with the demotion.

Luc Mbah a Moute (knee) questionable Tuesday: Mbah a Moute has missed the past two games with the knee issue, but we'll have a better idea on his status following Tuesday morning's shootaround. If he's out again, Danilo Gallinari and Montrezl Harrell will split his minutes.

James Ennis (hamstring) out Tuesday vs. POR: The Rockets initially said that Ennis would miss at least two games with a Grade 2 hamstring strain, which severely undershot the mark. He could be out a few weeks with this injury, which will result in more minutes for Carmelo Anthony and Gerald Green with Melo getting the start. Ennis shouldn't be owned anywhere, and it's not clear when he'll be back.

Mitchell Robinson will start again on Monday: David Fizdale will go with the same starting five from last Friday featuring Frank Ntilikina, Damyean Dotson, Tim Hardaway Jr., Noah Vonleh and Robinson with Enes Kanter coming off the bench. That starting group did play fairly well through the first three quarters of action against the defending champs, and Fizdale said he thought that lengthy lineup helped his team on defense. Mitchell sticking with the starting group is an excellent sign regarding his long-term outlook, so he's on the radar as a potential speculative add in deep leagues.

Delon Wright (groin) probable for Monday: Considering Wright tweaked his groin in his first game of the season on Wednesday, the Raptors will likely be taking it easy on him as he works his way back into the rotation. Even when he's 100% healthy, it's tough to see him as anything more than a low-end guy in deep leagues. For now, he can remain on the waiver wire.

Emmanuel Mudiay (ankle) available to play: Mudiay will likely be making his regular-season debut tonight, but we'd expect his minutes to be held in check in his first game of the season. Head coach David Fizdale did say that he may start Mudiay at some point, but for now, he's safe to leave on the wire in all leagues.

Brown says Wilson Chandler 'not that far off': To be clear, Chandler will miss Monday's game against the Hawks, but he does appear to be trending in the right direction. This is great news for Chandler after Brown said a couple weeks ago that he was still 'a ways away,' so maybe he'll be able to get back at some point during this five-game week for Philly. It's unlikely he'll have much value in fantasy hoops this season, but having him in the rotation could hurt Dario Saric.

Sindarius Thornwell headed for G-League stint: The Clippers have a ton of depth in their backcourt, so it would take a string of injuries for Thornwell to emerge as a rotation player in Los Angeles. Leave him on the wire.

Dillon Brooks (foot) probable for Tuesday: Brooks has been dealing with this foot issue since the season opener, but so far, he's only missed one game. In Memphis, probable tends to mean 'will play,' and we should get official confirmation on his status following Tuesday morning's shootaround. He's not a fantasy factor, though.

Steven Adams (calf) questionable for Tuesday: Adams was a late scratch on Sunday with the calf issue, which resulted in Nerlens Noel drawing the start, but Noel tweaked his ankle on Sunday and is now also questionable for Tuesday's game. If both these guys are out, Jerami Grant may see playing time in the 40s. We'll have a better idea on Adams' status following Tuesday morning's shootaround.

Nerlens Noel, Adams questionable for Tuesday: Noel tweaked his ankle during the fourth quarter of Sunday's win over the Suns, and if both him and Adams are out on Tuesday, OKC may be forced to start Patrick Patterson and Jerami Grant in their frontcourt. Check back for another update following Tuesday morning's shootaround.

James Harden unlikely to return before Friday: Harden is scheduled to be re-evaluated on Thursday before the Rockets leave for a five-game road trip. Coach Mike D'Antoni said Harden is 'making good progress' and he left the door open for him to return as soon as Saturday's game vs. Chicago on the second night of a back-to-back. Owners who have to submit weekly lineups should look at other options.
76ers pick up Ben Simmons' option: They also exercised the third-year options on Markelle Fultz and Dario Saric. This is just a formality and a no-brainer for the front office.

Andre Iguodala (calf tightness) is probable: It's the second night of a back-to-back and Iggy has been banged up, so maybe the Warriors limit his minutes tonight. He's not a standard-league option and has been very underwhelming this season.

Brandon Ingram says he will start Monday: He's been suspended for the past four games after his altercation with the Rockets. Ingram said he didn't know the starting lineup, but made it clear that he was going to be in the first unit. This means Kyle Kuzma or Josh Hart will head back to the bench, but we'll have to wait until closer to tip-off before we know for sure.

Aron Baynes (hamstring) could return Tuesday: This is great news for Boston because they just learned that Daniel Theis (foot) is out indefinitely. If Baynes is cleared, he'll slot right back in as the backup center, but there's not much fantasy appeal. If he's not able to play, the Celtics might give Robert Williams a chance. The Celtics will list Baynes as probable.

Theis has a slight tear of the plantar fascia: That's the bad news. The good news is that Theis won't need surgery and he'll be re-evaluated in a couple weeks. Coach Brad Stevens said he was relieved that the diagnosis wasn't worse, but it's safe to assume the Celtics won't rush him back. Marcus Morris will continue to see a bump in minutes off the bench, and with Aron Baynes (hamstring) still hurt, maybe the Celtics give Robert Williams an opportunity.
Darius Miller (right quad) ruled out: He was originally listed as doubtful, so no surprise here. Wes Johnson and Solomon Hill will pick up some minutes, but there isn't a clear fantasy pickup.

Anthony Davis (elbow) ruled out again: This comes from a report from Yahoo's Chris Haynes, so we don't have comments from coach Alvin Gentry or Davis yet. This is the second game in a row on the sidelines for Davis, but the fact that he's been initially labeled as questionable suggests that he's day-to-day. Nikola Mirotic and Jrue Holiday will get a lot more touches on offense, and Julius Randle will look to bounce back after getting in foul trouble vs. Rudy Gobert in his last game.
Rodions Kurucs (ankle) out Monday: He has made a strong impression, but minutes won't be easy to find now that Rondae Hollis-Jefferson is back.
Devin Harris (hamstring) out again Monday: He has no timetable for a return and may not be in the rotation when he comes back.
Kosta Koufos (hamstring strain) is probable: Koufos isn't in Sacramento's plans right now and probably won't play if he's cleared.

Ersan Ilyasova to start for Giannis on Monday: Concussions are tricky because their timetables are all over the place, but Ilyasova is a nice streaming option in the short term. In 43 starts last season, he put up 11.7 points, 5.9 rebounds, 1.2 assists, 0.9 steals and 1.4 triples. The rest of the Bucks' starting lineup will benefit as well, as Giannis leads the NBA in usage rate.

Markieff Morris questionable for Tuesday: The Wizards will evaluate him soon to determine whether or not he will be placed in the concussion protocol. The Wizards are dropping like flies and very little frontcourt depth right now. Kelly Oubre looks like the big winner if Morris sits, as he's been logging a ton of minutes in small-ball lineups. Jeff Green also benefits as well.

Antetokounmpo (concussion) ruled out Monday: The Raptors may have anticipated this because they have already decided to rest Kawhi Leonard. Giannis said he blacked out on Saturday when he took an elbow to the head, so it's hard to believe the Bucks let him return to that one. The entire starting lineup gets a bump with Giannis' league-leading usage rate out of the picture, and we could see more of Donte DiVincenzo, Tony Snell and Ersan Ilyasova.

Luka Doncic (back) listed as questionable: The Mavs are calling it lower back soreness. Doncic also banged his knee on Sunday night and this is the second game of a back-to-back, so maybe they play it safe and hold him out. If Luka can't go, Dennis Smith Jr. and J.J. Barea will get a bump in usage, while Maxi Kleber could be more involved as well.

OG Anunoby (personal) ruled out Monday: He was expected to return tonight, but Kawhi Leonard (rest) was also expected to play. Siakam played a season-high 37 minutes with OG out of the lineup on Friday, scoring 10 points with seven rebounds, three assists and one steal.

Andrew Wiggins (quad) is a game-time call: Wiggins has missed two games in a row, but he's had the entire weekend off to get right. The Wolves will make a decision after warmups, but if he can't go, Josh Okogie could get another start and Derrick Rose will get a nice bump in value off the bench.

Kawhi Leonard will rest on Monday vs. MIL: Welp. Coach Nick Nurse said on Sunday that there was 'no plan' to sit Leonard, but Leonard's camp may be calling the shots here. This is the second game that Kawhi will miss and his fantasy owners are just hoping that this doesn't become a trend. He'll be back in the lineup on Tuesday vs. Toronto. With OG Anunoby (personal) out again, Pascal Siakam looks like a nice option after playing 37 minutes in his last game. Kyle Lowry and Danny Green also get a bump.

Brown not worried about Dario Saric: 'I dont think its anything to do with the league scouting him differently,' Brown said. 'I think it maybe does have to do with a little bit of burnt energy. Its the toil of a summer (Saric spent the summer with the Croatian national team). This notion, that you play 12 months and youre really in a good flow, is a myth. It is a myth. People need rest.' Saric is shooting 38.2% from the field and 27% from deep this season, but it's just a matter of time before he heats up and Philly plays five times this week.

Wolves demanding Eric Gordon in Butler talks: We already know Houston has offered up to four first-round picks, but that offer didn't include Gordon. Butler is one of the best two-way players in the league and the Rockets are all-in on their pursuit of a championship, but it sounds like the talks have stalled once again.

Jaylen Brown frustrated with slow start: 'Its been a little frustrating,' Brown said. 'At the end of the day, youve got to make plays and hit shots. Im trying to find a rhythm, trying to take the right shots. Thats what Im looking for.' He finally came alive for 19 points with two rebounds, one assist, one steal, one block and three 3-pointers in 25 minutes on Saturday, so hopefully that is a sign of things to come. Coach Brad Stevens hasn't lost confidence in Brown and believes he's been playing with 'unbelievable energy,' so it will be interesting to see if he can build off that performance on Tuesday vs. Detroit.

Wilson Chandler (hamstring) out Monday: Chandler did not meet his initial target date and is progressing slower than expected.  Coach Brett Brown said that Chandler is still 'a ways away' when asked last week, so we see no reason to stash him in most leagues.

Fizdale: Kanter responded well to benching: 'He sees himself as a starter too and I understand that,' Fizdale said. 'Im looking for combinations. He had a great practice today. He came to work. Brought good energy, was great in the film.' We were worried about Kanter because he's on an expiring contract on a tanking team, and Fizdale wants to take an extended look at Noah Vonleh and Mitchell Robinson. Kanter is still an excellent per-minute fantasy contributor and could have mid-round value if he plays minutes in the mid-20s. Whether or not this move to the bench is permanent remains to be seen, but Kanter's owners shouldn't panic.

D'Angelo Russell thinks he complements LeVert: 'I think we both are able to play off the ball. Were both able to create. We just flow. Weve got a chemistry thats connecting well together,' Russell said. 'I think the next step is getting other guys involved at the same time and finishing games.' They combined for 48 points and 13 assists against the Warriors on Sunday, and coach Kenny Atkinson said he likes their chemistry as well. Russell is heating up after a slow start with 23.3 points, 6.0 assists, 4.0 rebounds and 4.3 triples over his last three games.

Tyler Johnson's rotation spot in jeopardy?: Goran Dragic, Rodney McGruder and Josh Richardson are all guaranteed big minutes right now, and Johnson is shooting 35.9% from the field and 3 of 18 on 3-pointers this season. Wayne Ellington will make his season debut any day now, and the Heat haven't even gotten Dion Waiters (ankle) or James Johnson (hernia) back yet. Johnson is an easy drop candidate.

Woj: Kevin Love could miss more than a month: Woj adds that the 'intense pain and the combination of an 0-6 start make it less logical for Love to push through the injury.' Love will consult with doctors early this week, but his fantasy owners should be prepared for a lengthy absence. At this point, Love's owners should be rooting for a trade so he can salvage this season later in the campaign -- the shut-down risk is extremely high on the tanking Cavs. Larry Nance should be owned everywhere, while Cedi Osman will try to get going after a tough week.

John Wall shoots 8-of-20, Wizards now 1-5: Wall didn't make a 3-pointer and the silver lining is that he racked up steals while committing just one turnover in 28 minutes. Prior to the game, Wizards head coach Scott Brooks emphasized defense as the key, but they lost 136-104 in L.A. tonight with the Clippers shooting 54.4% as a team. The Wizards are unintentionally tanking but it's safe to assume that Wall, Bradley Beal and Otto Porter will continue to check the necessary boxes for fantasy owners.

Boban Marjanovic plays well...in 12 minutes: The 7'3' center made only 1-of-4 free throws, but he sank 6-of-7 field goals for his first double-digit scoring performance since Oct. 19. The lopsided score tonight obscures any takeaways from Boban's activity, especially since he played a combined 10 minutes in L.A.'s previous three games. He's more of a handcuff for Montrezl Harrell and Marcin Gortat in deep leagues.

Lou Williams scores 17 points in 16 minutes: Williams also dished out six assists with one steal and only one 3-pointer. That efficiency is key to his fantasy appeal, and his 28.6% usage is comparable to last year's 29.8%, when he unexpectedly dropped top-50 roto value. The Clippers' backcourt is deeper this season and Sweet Lou's owners should be relieved that they have a 4-2 record -- if they stay in the mix for a playoff spot, the odds of tanking decrease dramatically.

Markieff Morris (flu) scoreless in 14 minutes: Morris was a game-time decision and fantasy owners probably wish he'd sat it out. He missed all four of his field goal attempts, grabbed one rebound, and did nothing else statistically. The Wizards' road trip continues in Memphis on Tuesday and we expect 'Kieff to fare better vs. rookie Jaren Jackson Jr. in that game.

Montrezl Harrell cools off Sunday in 16 mins: Boban Marjanovic has been used situationally and starter Marcin Gortat is averaging a mere 17.0 minutes, partly due to Harrell's effective play off the bench. Harrell shot just 1-of-4 from the line tonight, however, and the center minutes were spread evenly between himself, Gortat (20) and Marjanovic (12). He's a great DFS play until the price increases, but season-long owners can't really trust him as more than a FG% specialist.

Milos Teodosic aids Clips to 2nd straight win: The veteran attempted only one shot, a made 3-pointer, and he's still far off the fantasy map. Doc Rivers has been going small with Luc Mbah a Moute (sore left knee) out of commission, and the Clippers have won two straight, so there's at least some daylight in very deep leagues.

Kelly Oubre shoots 2-of-12 in loss vs. Clips: Oubre made 4-of-4 free throws but just 1-of-7 shots from deep, and his inefficiency can't bode well with teammate Bradley Beal, who said prior to the game, 'We suck right now.' The Wizards are 1-5 and the silver lining for fantasy owners is that they're unlikely to tank with a massive payroll.

Shai Gilgeous-Alexander goes 10-8-7-2 Sunday: SGA just keeps plugging away and tonight's line featured career highs in rebounds and assists, and he tied his career highs with the 3-pointer and two steals. He's trending up and while it might take an injury to Patrick Beverley to finally set him free, there's plenty of intrigue with SGA. He's not a must-own player, but if you have room to stash him, do it.

Ian Mahinmi plays season-high 29 minutes: Mahinmi made 3-of-5 field goals and 5-of-6 free throws, but this was an aberration for multiple reasons. Starting center Dwight Howard (back) was out again, and Mahinmi hadn't played this many minutes since the 2015-16 postseason. Leave him on the wire.

Austin Rivers quiet in game vs. Doc, Clippers: Rivers was playing vs. his former team, with his father as the opposing coach, and he acknowledged his unique situation prior to the game. 'Lets call it for what it is,' he said. 'I played for my father in the NBA, thats crazy.' He's been a non-entity for fantasy and there's no reason to think that will change as the Wizards try to claw back from a 1-5 start to the season.

Patrick Patterson scores 17 points on 10 FGA: Patterson threw down his first dunk as a member of the Thunder, and seemed rejuvenated to see some shots go in tonight. According to beat writer Brett Dawson, Patterson was 'clearly frustrated' with his shots not falling early this season, and has been 'putting in some extra work.' It paid off tonight but his workload was the product of Steven Adams (calf) being unavailable, so there's no reason to touch him in 12-team leagues.

Rudy Gobert erupts with 23 & 16, three blocks: Gobert made 9-of-13 field goals and 5-of-6 free throws, and five of his rebounds came on the offensive glass. He's opened the season with six consecutive double-doubles and there's no reason to think he'll slow down, especially if Derrick Favors (knee) misses more time. Utah improved to 4-2 tonight and life is good for Gobert's fantasy owners.

Jae Crowder steps up, scores 15 w/ Favors out: Derrick Favors (left knee soreness) was out tonight and the veteran Crowder stepped up in his absence. It's unclear how long Favors might be sidelined, but Crowder was already on the threshold of fantasy value with averages of 11.6 points, 1.6 triples, 5.6 rebounds, 2.4 assists and 0.6 steals. He's an intriguing DFS play if Favors misses more time, but most season-long owners can wait for higher-upside options. Crowder also appeared to tweak his right ankle late in Sunday's game, but there's no reason to suspect it will cause him to miss games.

Georges Niang scores 13 points in 13 minutes: Niang sank two 3-pointers but added just one rebound without any assists or defensive stats. His 13 minutes were a season-high tonight, and that's due to the absence of  Derrick Favors (left knee), so there's very little upside here.

Ricky Rubio recedes after Saturday's surge: Rubio made a 3-pointer tonight but he went 1-of-2 at the line and was generally disappointing after a breakthrough game on Saturday -- 28 points, 12 assists and six boards with efficient shooting. He's had many slow starts throughout his career but tends to finish strong, so patient owners shouldn't give up on him. Just remember that he was a top-50 player after the All-Star break last year.

Elie Okobo has career night Sunday: This was easily his best game of the young season and it came on a night when Isaiah Canaan left early with a sprained left ankle in the first quarter. The Suns already have nothing to play for and it would make sense for them to just let the kids play, and learn something in the process. We don't know the severity of Canaan's injury yet, but if you've got an extra bench spot sitting empty, or with some dead weight, taking a flier on Okobo might make sense. The Suns have said they'll trade for a veteran point guard, but that doesn't mean they will. And with Devin Booker (hamstring) also hurt, Okobo could be in line for some nice minutes in his upcoming three-game week.

Jalen Brunson quiet in 12 minutes w/ DSJ back: Brunson started Friday's game with Dennis Smith Jr. sidelined by a sprained ankle, but with DSJ sidelined he was relegated to a backup role. The takeaway here is that he's the clear-cut No. 2 at point guard and looks like a solid handcuff for DSJ in deep leagues.

DeAndre Jordan nears triple-double: 19/12/9: DJ's previous career-high was six dimes. He has shown renewed energy with Dallas this year and is racking up early-round fantasy value as a result -- he came in averaging 16.0 points (63.0% FGs, 84.6% FTs), 13.8 boards, 2.0 dimes, 2.0 blocks and 0.6 steals. The free-throw shooting is fluky but his owners aren't complaining, as he currently has a more positive impact at the line than a bunch of FT studs including Jimmy Butler. There's no reason to think he'll drop off as the season progresses, but anything is possible if the 2-4 Mavs eventually fall out of the playoff picture.

Harrison Barnes shoots 3-of-13 on Sunday: A strained right hamstring cost Barnes training camp and the first four games of the regular season. He's still working back to his typical form and is just 8-of-30 from the field (26.7%) in two games, so owners may need to consider benching him until he warms up. He won't contribute many across-the-board stats but is typically a reliable contributor for points and 3-pointers with solid percentages.

T.J. Warren bounces back with 18 points: He scored just three points on Saturday, playing just 18 minutes in a blowout loss to the Grizzlies, but has been the Suns best small forward this season. He got back on track tonight, but will likely struggle on nights Trevor Ariza and Josh Jackson get hot, assuming that ever happens again. Of the three SFs in Phoenix, TJW has easily been the most consistent thus far, despite Saturday's dud.

Josh Jackson quiet in another start: He was also 0-for-3 from downtown, and just can't seem to find his way this season. He's scored eight or fewer points in four of his six games, and has scored eight points in both of his starts. It's early and there's plenty of time for him to get it turned around, but with Trevor Ariza and T.J. Warren playing the same position, Jackson just hasn't been able to get right, even with Devin Booker out with his hamstring injury.

Luka Doncic OK after minor left knee injury: It wasn't all good news, as the rookie shot 5-of-13 from the field with five turnovers in the Mavs' fourth loss of the season. Doncic checked out after his knee injury in the third quarter, but he didn't miss much time and there's no reason to think he's in danger of missing Monday's road game in San Antonio.

Dennis Smith Jr. hits 12-of-19 FGs for 27 pts: DSJ was returning from a right ankle injury that cost him one game, but he obviously didn't miss a beat. Efficiency has been an issue for his fantasy value but after tonight's performance he's making 48.2% of his shots, up from just 37.5% last season. Luka Doncic's playmaking could take the ball out of his hands more than owners would like, and it remains to be seen if he can sustain efficient shooting, but the early returns are encouraging. His return sent Jalen Brunson back to fantasy irrelevance.

Ryan Anderson scores season-high 15 in loss: This was his first trip to double-digit scoring this season, as well as his best game of the year. The 31 minutes were easily a season high and it's possible he's on the verge of getting hot and producing. But he's getting up there at 30 years old, and had been pretty terrible up to this point. We'll need to see it again before thinking about taking the bait.

Jerami Grant scores season-high 14 in start: Now that he's finally in the starting lineup, he could get hot, although he was helped tonight by the fact that Steven Adams was out with a calf injury. Grant's not a must-own player, especially with just three games next week, but he's worth keeping a close eye on as one of the only power forward options, along with Patrick Patterson, in OKC.

Russell Westbrook scores 23 despite shoulder: He now has 16 turnovers in just three games, and has made only one 3-pointer after not even attempting one tonight. He only played four games last season in which he didn't attempt a 3-pointer, so this was a bit of a rarity. It looks like his shoulder injury is becoming a thing of the past and he's not on a minutes limit. The Thunder play three times in Week 3, and Westbrook will hopefully be good to go in all of them.

Nerlens Noel explodes in start for Adams: Those were easily season highs across the board and his previous highs were nine points, seven rebounds and 15 minutes. Yes, he did this against the lowly Suns, and yes, Adams will be back soon enough, but you have to think Noel earned some more playing time, at least in the near future, with this performance. He left the game briefly after taking a shot to the head in the third quarter, but wasn't gone for long. There's no reason to jump on Noel after one good game, but this should officially start your radar on him. And if Adams is ruled out for more games, Noel should be worth using for as long as he's out. And in case you're wondering, the last time he scored at least 20 points in a game was when he had 24 points on Feb. 19 - of 2016! It's just nice to know he can still play.

Markieff Morris (flu) will start on Sunday: Ian Mahinmi and Otto Porter will join him in the Wizards' frontcourt tonight. Morris has quietly surged past his average draft position in fantasy leagues, aided by small-ball center minutes without Dwight Howard (back), so keep trotting him out there.

Markieff Morris (flu) is a game-time decision: He'll warm up prior to making a final call on his status, which is mildly encouraging. If he can't suit up, the Wizards would be even thinner in the frontcourt and we'd expect Ian Mahinmi, Jeff Green and Jason Smith to log extra minutes.

Isaiah Canaan exits w/ sprained left ankle: The Suns were trailing by nearly 20 points prior to halftime and Devin Booker (hamstring) is out tonight, so there was no real need for Canaan to play at less than 100 percent. We're considering him questionable for Wednesday's game vs. the visiting Spurs.

Luc Mbah a Moute (knee) ruled out Sunday: Danilo Gallinari and Montrezl Harrell stand to gain the most, but this doesn't have a huge fantasy impact since Mbah a Moute was averaging a modest 15.3 minutes per game. We're considering him day-to-day going forward.

Kevin Durant racks up 34/8/6 and extras: KD made 11-of-20 field goals and 10-of-11 free throws in yet another ultra-efficient offensive performance. The eventual return of DeMarcus Cousins is the only background concern for Durant owners, as Cousins' usage could take a chunk of touches away from both KD and Steph Curry, but that's no reason to fret. He's simply a lock for elite value as long as he's healthy.

Draymond Green dishes season-high 13 dimes: Green didn't get to the free-throw line and missed all three of his 3-point attempts, leaving him at just 27.3% from deep on the season. Defenses continue to abandon him at the arc, but his fantasy value shouldn't change much whether or not he knocks them down or scores more than his current 8.0 points per game. As long as the dimes and defensive stats are there, he'll be fine.

Alfonzo McKinnie solid in 17 bench minutes: McKinnie made 4-of-5 shots with just one turnover off the bench, and he's quietly carving out a role with Patrick McCaw's contract dispute dragging into November. This was his most well-rounded game of the season for fantasy purposes, though, and he's nowhere near standard-league value.

Stephen Curry has NBA record w/ seven more 3s: Curry has made 48 three-pointers this season, which is more than the combined totals for multiple teams at this early stage of the season -- the Cavaliers (43), Clippers (41), Nuggets (40) and Thunder (33). He's the first player in NBA history to make at least five 3-pointers in seven straight games, and has joined Anthony Davis as the top fantasy assets at this early point in the season. He's already building a case for his third MVP award. The threat of a few late-season DNPs was enough to drop his draft position in many leagues, and owners who scored him in the 6-10 range have to be thrilled with the early returns.

Allen Crabbe scores season-high 14: The rise of Caris LeVert and the strong play of Joe Harris are going to hurt Crabbe's fantasy value going forward, but he does appear to be over his ankle injury. And this was a far cry from his 0-for-7 shooting night last Wednesday. Just keep an eye on him.

Caris LeVert trending back up: He started off the season hot, cooled off for a game last Wednesday, and has gotten back on track over his last two, scoring 23 and 21 points in each of them. He hasn't had a steal in a couple games, but the rest of his numbers are flowing, as his breakout season continues. He's a must-own fantasy player in all leagues.

Andre Iguodala (calf) plays 20 minutes Sunday: Shaun Livingston (right foot soreness) was out tonight and Iguodala led the Warriors' second unit in playing time, although that's not saying much. The former fantasy stud has been an afterthought since joining the Warriors in 2013 and there's no reason to own him outside of very deep leagues.

D'Angelo Russell scores season-high 25: He got off to a slow start this season, but has rendered Spencer Dinwiddie somewhat useless of late, and has really turned it on over his last two games. He's averaging 24.5 points, 5.5 rebounds, 5.0 assists and 5.5 3-pointers over his last two games, hitting 18-of-30 shots, good for 60 percent, and has also knocked down 11-of-17 3-pointers in his last two, good for 65 percent. Hopefully you didn't panic after the slow start.

Jarrett Allen solid in loss to Warriors: He's not blowing anyone's socks off with his production, but he's been quite solid from night to night. He was able to run with the Warriors tonight and helped to render both Damian Jones (2 points, 12 minutes) and Jordan Bell (2 points, 10 minutes) ineffective. Allen's still a breakout candidate, and should only get better with time. Just hang in there with him if you own him.

Joe Harris cools off from downtown: Harris entered the game at No. 4 in the league in 3-point percentage (59.3%), and hit his first two of the night. However, he missed his next four triples (and shots), but has still hit 15 of his last 23 shots from beyond the arc, good for 65 percent.
