He's been a bit quiet in his last two games, scoring just seven points in each of them, but if you are looking for 3-pointers in your fantasy league, he's probably available.
Jae Crowder starts for Derrick Favors (knee): Georges Niang should also benefit with Favors sidelined, but Crowder is the primary beneficiary. Check back after the game to see how he fared.

Nerlens Noel starts for Steven Adams (calf): This report hit after the 7pm lineup-lock so there will be more than a few frustrated Adams owners in DFS and weekly leagues. Noel's per-minute upside has never been doubted and he's worth a play if Adams misses more games, though this sounds like a minor ailment that won't cost him much time. Jerami Grant and Patrick Patterson should also benefit if Adams can't suit up.

Hamidou Diallo won't play Sunday: It's a disciplinary move from the Thunder which should result in more minutes for Alex Abrines and Terrance Ferguson, though neither guy is appealing as a DFS plug-and-play option. Expect Diallo to resume his typical bench role vs. the Clippers on Tuesday.

Fizdale says Mudiay could eventually start: To be clear, Fizdale will not be bringing Mudiay into the starting lineup initially, as his conditioning isn't quite where it needs to be after sitting out the first six games of the year. However, the fact that he's toying with the idea of starting Mudiay isn't great for Trey Burke and Frank Ntilikina's outlook. The point guard situation in New York is a mess and one that should be avoided in standard leagues.

Moe Harkless (knee) ruled out for Monday: Harkless was forced out of Saturday's game with the knee issue, and this is the same knee that gave him trouble during the preseason. Jake Layman and Evan Turner should split his minutes, but neither of those guys are all that attractive in fantasy hoops. Harkless belongs on the waiver wire in all leagues.
Alec Burks (hand) available to play Sunday: Burks is too inconsistent to trust in fantasy hoops.

Andrew Wiggins (quad) questionable Monday: Wiggins has missed the past two games for Minnesota, which has resulted in Josh Okogie moving into the starting lineup, and that trend should hold if Wiggins is out again tomorrow. Owners can expect to get another update following Monday morning's shootaround.

Antetokounmpo (head) questionable Monday: Antetokoumpo took an elbow to the head during Saturday's game, which he said caused him to briefly black out, but it's worth noting that he's not currently in the concussion protocol. We'll have a better idea on his status following Monday morning's shootaround, but if he's out, Ersan Ilyasova may move into the starting lineup and there will be more shots for the main guys in Milwaukee. Stay tuned.
D.J. Wilson (hamstring) out Monday vs. TOR: Yup.
Courtney Lee (neck) out Monday vs. Nets: Lee remains without an official timetable to return and belongs on the waiver wire in all leagues.

James Johnson (hernia) out Monday vs. SAC: Johnson has yet to make his regular-season debut, but he has been ramping up his activities at recent practices, which suggests he's getting close. Kelly Olynyk and Justise Winslow will continue to split the power forward minutes while Johnson is out.

Devin Harris (hamstring) out Sunday vs. UTA: Head coach Rick Carlisle did say that there's a chance Harris could play on Wednesday against the Lakers, but they aren't in any rush to get him back and don't want to push him. He'll be a negligible part of the rotation this season and belongs on the waiver wire in all leagues.

Julius Randle (foot) probable for Monday: Randle is dealing with plantar fasciitis in his left foot, which is one of the worst words you can read in basketball, but thus far that issue hasn't forced him to spend any time on the sidelines. Anthony Davis (elbow) is questionable for Monday's game, and if he's out, Randle will likely be getting another start.

Anthony Davis (elbow) questionable Monday: Davis missed Saturday's game against the Jazz, which resulted in Julius Randle moving into the starting five, and that's likely what will happen on Monday if AD can't play. Owners can expect to get another update following shootaround, but if he's out, Jrue Holiday, Nikola Mirotic and Randle should all see an uptick in usage, and Jahlil Okafor could see limited minutes off the bench. Stay tuned.

Darius Miller (quad) doubtful for Monday: Miller sat out Saturday's game against the Jazz, and it's looking like Monday will be his second straight game on the sidelines. Wes Johnson and Solomon Hill will split his minutes, but that doesn't mean much in fantasy hoops.

Elfrid Payton (ankle) ruled out for Monday: Payton exited Saturday's game after twisting his ankle, and while he was initially able to play through it, it seems that the ankle swelled up on him overnight. With Payton unavailable on Monday, we could see Tim Frazier enter the starting lineup and there will be more minutes for guys like Ian Clark and Frank Jackson. Jrue Holiday will also spend a bit more time running the offense.

Russell Westbrook (shoulder) will play Sunday: Westbrook sat out Saturday's practice with the shoulder issue, but there's been no word on a minutes limit, so owners shouldn't hesitate to get him active for a favorable matchup vs. Phoenix. Joining Westbrook in the starting five will be Paul George, Terrance Ferguson, Jerami Grant and Steven Adams.

Jalen Brunson will come off the bench Sunday: Dennis Smith Jr. (ankle) will be back in action tonight following a one-game stint on the sidelines, so Brunson's minutes will likely trend back towards the teens. He's not a viable target in most settings while the point guards in Dallas are healthy.

Dennis Smith Jr. (ankle) will play on Sunday: DSJ sat out Friday's game, but he'll be back out there tonight with his normal minutes, which will shift Jalen Brunson back to the second unit. Feel free to get him active.
Andre Iguodala (calf) will play on Sunday: Iguodala should see his normal minutes with the second unit today, but he's not bringing enough to the box score to warrant any attention in fantasy hoops.
Jarred Vanderbilt (foot) still 'a ways away': The Nuggets will bring him along slowly, but even when he's cleared to play, he'll be a non-factor in the rotation.
Justin Anderson (leg) out Monday vs. 76ers: He's yet to make his season debut and shouldn't be owned anywhere.

Shaun Livingston out Sunday; doubtful Monday: Livingston tweaked his right foot just prior to the season opener, and it appears it's developed into a nagging issue. With the 33-year-old guard set to miss the next two games, we'll see some more Quinn Cook with the second unit, but that doesn't mean much with Stephen Curry healthy.

Cavs weighing how long to sit Kevin Love: The Cavs just fired Tyronn Lue and are 0-6. Love is looking at a potential extended absence as the Cavs weather the storm. With Love out, everyone on the Cavs will see more looks and Larry Nance, Sam Dekker, and Channing Frye will see more time at power forward.

Thabo Sefolosha (left ankle) available Sunday: Sefolosha has yet to play this season and is unlikely to be a factor in the rotation for the Jazz. However, he could see an uptick in minutes with Derrick Favors set to miss this one.
Russell Westbrook (shoulder) questionable: Westbrook didn't practice on Saturday and with no shootaround on Sunday, he's shaping up to be a game-time decision. Stay tuned for updates.

Derrick Favors (knee) is out on Sunday: Favors hasn't looked healthy and has battled soreness in his knee for at least a week now. Jae Crowder stands to benefit a good bit from his absence. Georges Niang is also likely to see an uptick in minutes.
J.J. Barea (hamstring) probable on Sunday: Barea played through his hamstring issue on Friday and looks set to do so again on Sunday. He's decent source of assists in the short-term.

Dennis Smith Jr. (ankle) probable for Sunday: DSJ tweaked his ankle in Wednesday's game and did not play on Friday, with Jalen Brunson starting in his absence. He warmed up prior to Friday's game, but just didn't feel right. We'll know his status for sure a little bit later on. Stay tuned.

Shaun Livingston (foot) questionable Sunday: Livingston played just nine minutes in the Warriors' previous game and they'll likely proceed with caution with the veteran. Quinn Cook would see an increase in action with Livingston out.
Emmanuel Mudiay (ankle) probable for Monday: Mudiay is set to make his season debut. As it stands, he's not worth owning in any format.
Zhou Qi (knee) returns to practice Sunday: Qi has not played this season and is unlikely to be a factor in the Rockets' rotation with them at full strength.

Marquese Chriss (ankle) returns to practice: Chriss has a chance to earn minutes as the backup center, but isn't guaranteed to do so with Isaiah Hartenstein playing well. Chriss isn't worth a roster spot right now.
Dwight Howard (back) listed as out Sunday: Howard has yet to make his Wizards debut and seems unlikely to make it on Sunday. Ian Mahinmi will continue to start in his absence.

Andre Iguodala (calf) questionable for Sunday: Iguodala has dealt with this minor calf ailment for about a week now, but hasn't missed any game action. The Warriors will continue to monitor him closely. Jonas Jerebko and Alfonzo McKinnie would see more minutes in the event that Iguodala were to sit this one out.

Devin Booker (hamstring) out Sunday vs. OKC: Booker was able to get up some shots during shootaround, but he didn't have much lift on his jumper, which isn't a great sign regarding his status for Wednesday's game against the Spurs. Josh Jackson and Elie Okobo will see an uptick in minutes in Booker's absence, and Deandre Ayton will be very busy on offense.
Dzanan Musa recalled from Nets' G-League team: Musa as assigned to the G-League earlier on Sunday and it was probably just a procedural move. He's not on the fantasy radar.

No plan to sit Kawhi Leonard in back-to-back: 'We're gonna go play 'em,' Nurse said. 'He's feeling good and feeling fine, and we'll go from there.' Leonard sat out the second-half of the Raps' first back-to-back, but it's great to hear that he's healthy enough to not have them planning to sit him. He's been a stud so far and will continue to be one as long as he's playing.

Delon Wright, OG Anunoby expected back Monday: Wright came back and felt tightness in his injured groin, which limited him to five minutes in his season debut. He was likely to be limited in that game anyway, so they took no chances. Fred VanVleet is questionable, so the Raptors could use Wright off the bench. He's more important to his team than he is to fantasy owners and is best left as a free agent in most leagues.

OG Anunoby (personal) expected to play Monday: Anunoby didn't practice Sunday and still isn't with the team, but is expected to meet them in Milwaukee ahead of their matchup with the undefeated Bucks. He'll be tasked with trying to slow Giannis Antetokounmpo, which is helpful to the Raps but not helpful to fantasy owners. He's best left on the wire in most leagues.

Fred VanVleet (toe) questionable for Monday: VanVleet is a key cog in the Raptors bench unit, so they're playing it safe with him as he still has some pain. He was originally probable to play on Friday, but ended up being held out. Delon Wright is expected to return and should see an uptick in minutes if FVV were to miss his third straight game.

Dwyane Wade says Heat want to shoot 100 FGs: 'We didnt even reach our goal tonight,' Wade said. 'We wanted to shoot 100 shots. We didnt get there. We got close. Its fast-paced. Its get looks up, contested threes, open threes, rhythm threes. Thats just the game it is.' They took 96 shots, just shy of their stated goal. The Heat are embracing the league's fast-paced revolution, which is great for the fantasy outlook of their many relevant players. More shots means more opportunities to produce, as shown by the Heat having eight guys averaging points in double-figures.

Kevin Knox's (ankle) timetable is 2-3 weeks: The elder Knox said that his son did not suffer a high-ankle sprain and that his pain is now down to a 3 after it being a 9 immediately following the injury (on a scale of 1-10). Knox was getting some shots up at Knicks practice on Friday and is slowly getting closer to making his return. Damyean Dotson, Mario Hezonja, Allonzo Trier, Noah Vonleh, and Mitchell Robinson are among the guys benefiting from Knox's absence. We have yet to hear anything official from the Knicks.

Cristiano Felicio keeps playing over RoLo: Felicio even played the final 15 minutes over Wendell Carter Jr. because he was playing well. Lopez appears to be destined for a trade, making Felicio a potential add in deep-leagues and a cheap option in DFS moving forward.

Aron Baynes (hamstring) to be ready Tuesday?: Coach Brad Stevens said the team wanted to be cautious with Baynes, which is why he sat out on Saturday against the Pistons. His eventual return will take minutes from Daniel Theis, Guerschon Yabusele, and Marcus Morris.

'Just not enough time' for Wayne Ellington: 'Just wasnt enough minutes tonight,' Spoelstra said. 'But Wayne has been through this before. Two years ago, he was out for more than six weeks and he found his way back in. Its still early on. But I love the fact that hes back in uniform.' With Rodney McGruder playing well, Ellington might not see much time. The Heat are still without James Johnson and Dion Waiters, meaning minutes will be even tougher to come back for a few guys, including Ellington. He's safe to leave on the waiver wire.

Hassan Whiteside proves pivotal in big win: '[Whiteside] mentioned that he was just trying to do whatever he could to put his fingerprints on this win,' coach Erik Spoelstra said. 'And down the stretch, that was a couple big contests to force some misses and a couple big rebounds. And even the offensive rebound. Thats winning basketball.' Whiteside blocked six shots and secured 16 rebounds. The Heat have been much better with him on the floor this year, which is great for his fantasy value.
Dzanan Musa assigned to Nets' G-League team: Musa hasn't played much this season, even with the Nets numerous injuries. He was picked 29th in the 2018 Draft and the Nets like his long-term outlook.

Giannis Antetokounmpo (head) blacked out: He said all concussion tests were negative, which allowed him to return to the game in the fourth quarter. Even though tests were negative at the time, that doesn't mean symptoms won't crop up today or tomorrow. Hopefully that isn't the case, but concussions can be tricky. The Bucks next play on Monday 10/29.

Tyreke Evans (personal) is back with the team: 'I was late for practice,' said Evans. 'This is the most professional and team-oriented organization I have been with in my career. They deserve my best every day and I am disappointed in myself for causing a distraction that prevents me from being able to help my team tomorrow. I will do better.' Evans realizes he made a mistake and is ready to return to action.

Pau Gasol has first double-double of season: Gasol has only played more than 20 minutes once this season and looks unlikely to reach that number most nights. He's only blocked one shot thus far and that doesn't help his fantasy value. Pau is a low-end center in deeper leagues.

Dante Cunningham, scores four in start: He was out there to guard LeBron James and that was pretty much it. Cunningham has routinely been one of the lowest usage rate players among rotation options, and he doesn't add defensive stats. Leave him on the wire.
Davis Bertans doesn't score in start: He came off the bench in his four games this year, but he didn't start the second half. Bertans won't have much value while Rudy Gay is healthy.
Jakob Poeltl gets another DNP-CD: As talented as he is and as helpful as he was in Toronto, coach Gregg Popovich just doesn't trust Poeltl yet.

Rudy Gay doesn't start, still double-doubles: Gay didn't start the first half, but did start the second half. Coach Gregg Popovich has juggled his lineups based on matchups so far this year and Gay was impacted by that tonight. Still, he was very productive and still managed 33 minutes. He has two consecutive double-doubles and should be a reasonably steady contributor moving forward.

Marc Gasol puts up 19/8/3, 3 steals in win: That scary neck issue was an afterthought as the Grizzlies handled their business on offense to put this game away early. Thanks to a 42-point fourth, they had a 25-point lead at half to tie largest halftime lead in a home game since a 25-point edge in 2005. As for Gasol, his fantasy owners may want to sell high at their best opportunity given his injury history and at age 33.

DeMar DeRozan nears triple-double w/ 30/12/8: DeRozan was a big reason why the Spurs came back to win against the Lakers. He's not attempting many triples, but he's still scoring at a steady rate. Add on his assists and he's been an exceptional fantasy option so far. The Spurs need him to handle and score and he's been doing both so far. He's scored 28+ in four of his first five games with the Spurs. He's going to have a big year.

Jaren Jackson Jr. scores six in 15 minutes: Foul trouble got him this time and that issue has re-surfaced with 5.0 fouls over his last four. That aside, JJJ is cleaning up with blocks and has a steal in each game -- three in the opener. With JaMychal Green still out, Jackson Jr. will have plenty of leash to improve on his mistakes. Maybe this could be a mini-opportunity to buy low.

Dillon Brooks score eight in 27 minutes: He had a good amount of volume in his rookie season, but the Grizzlies have a decent NBA roster this time around. Brooks won't offer enough upside in most leagues.

MarShon Brooks loves garbage time: Garbage time special here with 10 in the fourth to make his night. He may stay in the rotation because of the injury to Chandler Parsons (knee), but he's only worth a flier in deep leagues.

Lonzo Ball scores just 6 points in 27 minutes: Ball remained in the starting lineup with Rajon Rondo back from suspension, but he saw less court time. In the three games without Rondo, Ball averaged 6.7 assists. In the three games with Rondo, Ball has averaged just 2.7 assists. The Lakers have a lot to figure out with their rotation and it looks like Lonzo will be inconsistent for the near future. Better days are ahead.

Aaron Gordon hits 3-of-15 shots in loss: He missed all six of his triples, adding five rebounds, two assists and one steal. On the bright side, he was the only starter that played more than 27 minutes, so hopefully his floor will be safer in future blowouts -- those are quite common in Orlando.

Kyle Anderson scores two points in 21 minutes: Yeah, so Slow-Mo has been more like No-Go. Nobody expected Anderson to light up the scoring column, but 3.8 points per game over his first five is not gonna cut it. He's not having much offense go through him, the defensive stats haven't been there and he's only playing 21.9 minutes per game. He's looking like a drop in shallower formats or for a hotter free agent.

Rajon Rondo plays 29 minutes in return: Rondo came off the bench but still saw 29 minutes in Saturday's loss. He's clearly a big part of the Lakers plans, at least for now. He's been seeing staggered minutes with LeBron, but gets time closing out games. Rondo's also hit at least one triple in his three games this year, which would be a great development for his fantasy value. The Lakers have a lot to sort out with Brandon Ingram returning next game and Lonzo Ball and Josh Hart emerging. Still, Rondo remains a fantasy option due to his assists.

Deandre Ayton drops a 24/8/5 line in loss: Impressive. Sure, a lot of his stats came when the game was decided, but the Suns got much more than they bargained for with his touch on offense and his excellent passing out of the post. Ayton is more than just a rim-running big and it's hard to believe he's played just five NBA games, averaging 17.8 points, 10.2 boards, 0.8 blocks and 0.6 steals on 69.6 FG% and 84.6 FT%. He looks like the real deal.

Nikola Vucevic scores 16 points vs. MIL: Don't read into the low minutes because this game was over in a hurry. Vucevic was the 10th ranked fantasy player in 9-category leagues entering tonights game and Mo Bamba doesnt appear to be a threat to his workload right now. In fact, coach Steve Clifford said Bamba is not anywhere near ready to start and gushed about Vucevics play. It also helps that Orlando lacks a starting-level PG, as Vucevic is on pace for a career-high in assists (4.8). Hes crushing his ADP and fantasy owners should enjoy the ride.

Mo Bamba plays 23 minutes vs. Bucks: The Magic cant really use Bamba next to Nikola Vucevic for long stretches right now, as that combo has a brutal -62.5 net rating through the first five games. Sure it's a small sample size, but its just something the rookie isnt ready for. Hes more of a stash for blocks-needy owners with Vucevic dominating in the first unit.

Elie Okobo has nice night vs. Grizzlies: It was good showing in his first shot at the rotation with Devin Booker (hamstring) out. Okobo has good fundamentals on offense and he's been a good cutter since Vegas, so that could translate for when the Suns want to put him next to Booker eventually. Just keep an eye on him in super deep leagues.

Donte DiVincenzo scores 15 points vs. ORL: DiVincenzo was playing 20.0 minutes per game prior to Saturday, taking some of the minutes that Tony Snell had last season. He hasnt been very productive yet with 6.2 points, 3.4 rebounds, 1.8 assists, 0.4 blocks, 0.4 steals and 1.0 triples prior to Saturday, but its starting to look like he will benefit the most if any of the starting five picks up an injury.

Josh Jackson has a brutal night in start: Yeah, 0.4 points per possession is not good. Since summer league, Jackson continues to take shots he shouldn't and try to make plays that aren't there. He's lost a lot of his momentum he built from January to April, but the Suns will likely let him have his growing pains. Devin Booker (hamstring) should be back soon, so that could get Jackson back into his comfort zone.

LeBron James drops season-high 35 w/11 boards: After three straight double-digit assists games, LeBron posted a season-low four assists. It's no coincidence that Rajon Rondo returned from a 3-game suspension tonight. LeBron's not handling the ball as much with Rondo in the lineup and the assist totals show that. Still, LeBron is a fantasy monster no matter how much we nitpick.

Malcolm Brogdon scores 16 points in easy win: Brogdon is flirting with top-100 value and was averaging 11.6 points, 4.4 assists, 3.2 rebounds, 0.8 steals and 1.6 triples in 31.6 minutes entering tonights game. 'Complete credit to [coach Mike Budenholzer], not only do we have a great system that plays to our strengths...but he takes care of our bodies,' Brogdon said. 'We don't feel run down.' The Bucks are off to their best start in franchise history (6-0) and their entire starting lineup is on pace to finish inside the top-100 in Buds fantasy-friendly offense.

Isaiah Canaan scores 11 in bad loss: He didn't really get a Devin Booker (hamstring) bump because the Suns went young. Booker isn't going to be out long, but Canaan could have some value for PG-needy owners.

Khris Middleton scores 18 points vs. ORL: Middleton is crushing it to begin the season, posting top-15 value in 9-category leagues. His elite true shooting percentage (70.8%) ranks in the top five among wings, and hes hitting 57.9% of his pull-up triples which ranks third in the NBA. Coach Mike Budenholzer encouraged him over the summer to cut out his mid-range shot and focus on 3-pointers, and were already seeing the dividends with 4.4 3-pointers per game compared to 1.8 last season.

T.J. Warren plays just 18 minutes: The Suns went heavy with their rookies and it hurt Warren's playing time in this ugly loss. This wasn't a concern heading into the night, so Warren's fantasy owners shouldn't panic yet. Devin Booker (hamstring) shouldn't be out long.

Giannis Antetokounmpo scores 19 in win: He went back to the locker room a couple of times after an early collision with Aaron Gordon, but fantasy owners can breathe easy because he's going to be just fine. Giannis is leading the NBA in usage rate (34.6%), and once his efficiency picks back up he should right back in the top-5 of 9-category rankings.

Mikal Bridges scores seven in 24 minutes: The Suns went back to their preseason rotation with Bridges as a backup wing, and that could continue while Devin Booker (hamstring) is out. Still, Bridges is nowhere near the fantasy map in 12-team leagues and he still hasn't shown any flashes dating back to Vegas.

Kelly Olynyk scores 19 points vs. Blazers: After playing 16 or less minutes in the opening three games, Olynyk has responded with back-to-back strong performances. He was 6-of-9 from the field and 4-of-5 from the line tonight, and he's averaging 15.0 points, 4.0 rebounds, 5.5 assists, 1.0 steals and 2.0 triples over his last two games. Now that he's hot again, Olynyk is worth a look in standard leagues if you're targeting points, triples, out-of-position assists and shooting percentages.

Nicolas Batum scores just 2 points in 31 mins: Batum has not shot the ball well of late and has ceded most play-making duties to Kemba Walker. Batum is still a nice source of stats across the board, but might not produce the 5+ assists per game we've become accustom to with Walker running the show. The Hornets have a bunch of young wings that are coming for his time, but Batum will continue to hold them off because of his versatility. Don't panic.
Ryan Anderson scores seven in 22 minutes: Even with the Suns losing depth, they're just not going to play Anderson big minutes.

Ryan Arcidiacono  goes off vs. Hawks: It was his best game as he dominated Trae Young to help the Bulls get the win.  Arcidiacono isn't exactly a top prospect despite his time at Villanova, so he would only be worth a speculative look in deep leagues. Even if he does beat out Cam Payne, Kris Dunn should be back next month.

Goran Dragic scores 28 points on 10-of-19 FGs: The Heat improved to 3-2 because of Dragic's heroics, and he added five assists, three boards and four triples in 35 minutes. He has now attempted at least 14 shots in four out of five games, but could lose some touches with the Heat finally getting some bodies back.

Bam Adebayo scores seven points: Hassan Whiteside is healthy and motivated, and Kelly Olynyk is starting to heat up after his slow start. With James Johnson nearing a return, we see no reason to stash Bam right now.

Wendell Carter Jr. posts double-double: He's from Atlanta and maybe that helped him get going after a rough start to his career.  The best news is Carter Jr. only had one foul and one turnover, so keeping those in check will go a long way. Rookies need time to get their feet wet and he has the starting job locked up, but WJC has enough upside to allow a lot leash in standard leagues.

Tyler Johnson scores seven points vs. POR: Wayne Ellington was cleared to return from his ankle injury, but picked up a DNP-CD. Johnson hasn't played well this season and is on thin ice, so there's a chance he loses some minutes in the near future. He belongs on the waiver wire in standard leagues.

Zach LaVine scores 27 points with 11 boards: Make it six straight with 20-plus points for the longest stretch of his career. He was a little sloppy as evident by the turnovers, and those elevated his usage rate to 33.5 on the year. His shot selection is getting a little worse after being almost flawless to start the year, but he's still at an outstanding 65.2 TS%. His scoring breakout continues and his owners should expect him to be around 25 per game.

Kemba Walker scores 37 on 31 shots in loss: Walker was one of two Hornets to take double-digit shots, with Jeremy Lamb being the other at just 12 attempts. Kemba is running the show and has the ball in his hands most of the time. Even though he couldn't get his shot to fall, he still managed to get to the line 14 times (12-of-14). Even when he's off, he's still producing. Kemba's a top-20 player going forward.

Justise Winslow makes season debut vs. POR: There's no way coach Erik Spoelstra is taking Rodney McGruder out of the starting lineup, so Winslow will likely continue anchoring the second unit. He's just a lukewarm pickup in deeper leagues and has some efficiency concerns.

Derrick Jones Jr. picks up a DNP-CD: Airplane Mode was cleared to play tonight and is healthy again, but may be out of the rotation for the time being with Justise Winslow back in the lineup. Jones Jr. belongs on the wire outside of dynasty formats.

Chandler Hutchison scores four: He did get some minutes at small forward next to Jabari Parker, but Hutchison isn't quite ready to be a contributor as a scorer and he's not going to add defensive stats. He'll likely need garbage time to put up value in deep of DFS leagues.

Wayne Ellington picks up a DNP-CD: His season debut will have to wait despite the Heat calling him 'available.' With the way Rodney McGruder has looked alongside Josh Richardson, Ellington's path to fantasy value isn't great.
Shaq Harrison makes Bulls debut: His minutes came as a wing, but Harrison did handle the ball a bunch. He had a good run in his brief time with a +6, but there's no need to add him almost anywhere.

Jusuf Nurkic scores five points vs. MIA: This was his first dud of the season and he ran into an in-form Hassan Whiteside, so his owners should cut him some slack. Zach Collins has made a case for a larger role, but Nurk Alert is still on pace to comfortably outperform his ADP. His owners should be in a good spot next week with five games on the schedule.

Cam Payne flops against the Hawks: Ryan Arcidiacono took over late in this game and coach Fred Hoiberg didn't want to go back to Payne. He had played well in his previous two, so his owners should stick with him.

Zach Collins scores 13 points vs. Heat: He played just six minutes in the first half with two quick fouls, but came alive in the second half. Collins was averaging 10.3 points, 5.5 rebounds, 1.0 assists, 2.3 blocks and 1.0 triples entering Saturday's game and has been a mid-round value despite playing around 20 minutes. With Portland playing five games next week, Collins is a great pickup in standard leagues to see if he can keep this going.

Robert Covington double-doubles w/ 4 blocks: Lord Covington stuffed the stat sheet and had a superb all-around game in this one. He had a late block on Kemba Walker that helped the Sixers seal the win. He struggled from the free throw line, but he's usually a good free throw shooter. He only posted four double-doubles last year with Ben Simmons in the fold. Nights like this are why RoCo is a valuable fantasy asset.

Jake Layman plays 12 minutes: Hes been hanging around 12 minutes per game this season despite being a 'starter.' Even with Moe Harkless knee flaring up again, Layman simply isnt relevant in most fantasy leagues. Evan Turner is the better deep-league pickup.

Trae Young struggles in favorable matchup: Ice Trae melted in this one, missing all six from deep and getting torched by Ryan Arcidiacono. Young continues to dominate the rock as one of the leaders in time of possession, his usage rate is better than expected and the Hawks are flying with an NBA-high 108.6 pace.

Evan Turner scores eight points vs. MIA: He might have a few more minutes coming his way, as Moe Harkless left knee flared up on him again and he wasnt able to return. Turner has been quiet up to this point with 9.8 points, 5.3 assists, 3.5 rebounds and 1.0 steals with no triples entering Saturdays game, and its unlikely that Harkless latest setback will catapult Turner into standard-league relevance.

Damian Lillard drops 42 points in loss to MIA: Apparently the heckling fan from Thursday is still in the back of Lillard's head. That's his 18th career game with 40+ points which moves him past Clyde Drexler for most in Trail Blazers history. He's got the Western Conference Player of the Week Award locked up as he's coming off a 41-point game vs. Orlando, and we're still feeling confident about calling him a top-10 fantasy asset the rest of the way.

DeAndre Bembry fills the defensive stats: Last season was about as bad as it could get, but this year he's making up ground. Coach Lloyd Pierce has praised Bembry's ability to break down defenses, and it's reflected in the rotation with Bembry getting at least 27 minutes in three of the last four. He's not quite standard-league material yet, but that could change if the Hawks unload some guys.

Joel Embiid (ankle) double-doubles w/ 27 & 14: It wasn't clear before the game whether or not Embiid would be limited by the ankle tweak he suffered in Friday's practice, but he removed all doubt once the game began. Embiid now has six consecutive double-doubles to start the season and has played 33+ minutes in each game. He'll have an injury scare every now and then, but he's a fantasy monster when he's available.

Ben Simmons double-doubles w/ just 3 dimes: Simmons posted a shockingly-low assist total tonight, but that's probably because he took a season-high 20 shots. Despite only three assists, he's still averaging over seven per game thus far. It was nice to see him in attack mode from the jump, but the efficiency obviously needs to be better. Simmons might be asked to be in attack mode more often with Markelle Fultz able to run the offense, too. Keep rolling Simmons out there with confidence.

Dewayne Dedmon posts 13 and 13, 5 blocks: He kept the Hawks in this game with a team-high +18. Dedmon looked like himself in this game after his avulsion fracture kept him out of camp and the first week of the season. Bigs can be tough to come by and the Hawks don't have Alex Poythress (knee) now, so Dedmon is worth a long look for anyone needing a big man.

Giannis Antetokounmpo (head) returns again: Giannis has been in and out for most of the game due to an early collision with Aaron Gordon. Hopefully we find out more information once the game concludes.

Rodney Hood scores 17 points in loss to IND: He had a 23.2 usage rate with Kevin Love (foot) sitting out another game and led the Cavaliers in points and shot attempts and was second to Cedi Osman in minutes. Hood was hitting just 38.6% of his shots before Saturday, but has scored in double digits in each game so far. Hood might be relevant for the foreseeable future because of the lack of talent in Cleveland.

Rudy Gobert posts 25 and 14 with 4 blocks: It was like he was playing college kids with easy shots around the rim all night, and owning the paint on defense.  Gobert has been automatic with the ball, making 76.9% from the field with a respectable 71.9% from the line to get him to a 78.2 TS% on his 15.5 usage rate. He's also playing at a 105.0 pace, so this could be Gobert's best year yet.

Sam Dekker quiet in a start: He was 3-of-7 from the field with no turnovers. Love has missed two games in a row with foot soreness and the 0-6 Cavaliers will be patient with him, but we don't see a reason to pick up Dekker yet. Larry Nance looks like the big winner.

Ricky Rubio scores 28 points in win over Pels: He needed this one after a putrid 21.9% from the field in his first four. Anyone who has owned Rubio in the past will tell you all about his dreadful starts over the last few years, but picked up speed down the home stretch like Seabiscuit. Rubio should hold mid-round value on the year and the extra pace could help his ceiling.

J.R. Smith plays six minutes: Cavaliers coach Ty Lue is on record saying he wants to get Smith more involved, but the front office wants him to focus on the younger guys. Its pretty obvious that Smith isnt going to be useful in fantasy leagues any time soon.

David Nwaba scores seven points: He played a total of six minutes across two appearances prior to Saturday, so hes still irrelevant in all fantasy leagues. As bad as Cleveland has been, this could set Nwaba up for more run as we get closer to the new year.

Larry Nance double-doubles w/ four dimes: That's a season-high in points and rebounds and he's now played 20+ minutes in three straight. Kevin Love (foot) is already banged, the Cavs are winless and have very little talent, so all signs point to Nance becoming one of Cleveland's top fantasy assets going forward. He should be owned in standard leagues and should have some starts coming his way.

Donovan Mitchell scores 22 points in easy win: He has been outstanding against two good teams, and he even gave Jrue Holiday the business all game. Mitchell dropped 38 points in Houston and he's back on track with efficiency, and he's handed out 13 dimes to just four turnovers in those two wins. Mitchell should lead the Jazz in scoring as he puts up early-round value in fantasy.

Bojan Bogdanovic scores 25 points vs. CLE: We can't overreact here, as Tyreke Evans (personal) did not suit up. His minutes are down a bit this season and he's been hit-or-miss with two single-digit scoring games through six contests, so he's just a borderline standard-league asset with limited upside.

Derrick Favors scores 10 in 19 minutes: Maybe it's his knee, but Favors has that look of a guy lacking explosiveness again. He does have two blocks in each of his last three games, so that's helped soften the blow of scoring just 9.8 points and 7.3 boards in his previous four. He may not be worth owning in shallower leagues with Jae Crowder getting a lot of run.

Dante Exum scores 11 in 18 minutes: The Exum non-PG talk hasn't exactly come to fruition, but he's excelled in his role behind Ricky Rubio. Exum may not hold much fantasy value now, but that would likely change if anything happened to the starting perimeter guys.
Giannis Antetokounmpo (head) not starting 3Q: It remains to be seen if this is related to his first half issue, but it likely is. We'll be sure to update as we know more.

Thaddeus Young scores 10 points: Hes playing about three fewer minutes per game this season, and his steals are down from 1.7 in 2017-18 to 1.0 this season. Maybe he can get his steals back up because he averaged 1.5+ takeaways in three straight seasons, but his FT% (42.9) is way down as well. If you want to drop him for a hot free agent its not a bad idea since Young will likely just be a late-round guy.

Nikola Mirotic scores 25 points: It was definitely his time to shine with Anthony Davis (elbow) out and Julius Randle being neutralized by Rudy Gobert. Mirotic did also play some minutes as the lone big, so that could be in the cards if AD needs to miss more time -- it's not a serious injury. Mirotic has been on fire all year and looks like a fantasy steal.

Cory Joseph scores seven points: Hes quietly having one of his best seasons yet with 9.0 points, 3.6 assists, 3.8 rebounds, 1.0 steals and 1.6 triples prior to Saturday. Tyreke Evans (personal) was out, so Joseph saw a season-high in minutes tonight. Darren Collison finally got back on track, so Joseph is still just a deep-league asset until further notice.

Jrue Holiday has another good stats game: That's two good games in a row for Holiday following 26 points on Friday, and he had a little flash and flare on the offensive side today. There was never any need to panic after Holiday's slow start and he should be back on track as an early-round player.

Myles Turner scores 15 points on 7-of-10 FGs: An aggressive Myles Turner isnt as common these days, with this being only his third game out of six with double-digit shot attempts. Hopefully tonight gives him some confidence to keep firing away, because he has nowhere to go but up with one of the safest floors in fantasy  hes pretty much a lock for top-50 value because he can get you two blocks per night with excellent percentages. If this game was a little closer, this line could have been a lot better.

Darren Collison scores 15 points w/ 6 dimes: Collison had really been struggling, but this was the perfect storm with Tyreke Evans (personal) out and the Cavaliers ranking 28th in defensive efficiency. He cruised to a top-50 finish last season, so his owners just need to hang in there and hope that tonight is a sign of things to come.

Julius Randle scores just 12 points: He'll be seeing Rudy Gobert in his dreams tonight with Gobert keeping Randle away from easy paint points, and Gobert owned him when the Jazz had the rock. Randle looked healthy and there's been no concern about his plantar fascia, so expect him to be a full go this week. Anthony Davis should be back, as well.

Frank Jackson capitalizes on minutes: He was behind Ian Clark in the rotation tonight with Elfrid Payton (ankle) hurt, but Jackson outplayed every Pelican guard not named Jrue Holiday. Jackson has looked terrific in a small sample in the preseason and in Vegas, so he could be a name to watch in super deep leagues.

Solomon Hill scores 11 in 20 minutes: He was the first forward off the bench as he came in for Julius Randle to push Nikola Mirotic to the five. Hill could see minutes close to 20 while Anthony Davis (elbow) recovers, but it doesn't sound like he'll be out long.

Jahlil Okafor gets in the rotation: He was the first true big off the bench and looks to be ahead of Cheick Diallo. Still, the Pelicans pace is not Okafor's style, despite his mostly vegan diet. Assuming Anthony Davis (elbow) isn't out for long, leave him on the wire just about everywhere.

Ian Clark scores two in 13 minutes: He picked up some extra rotation minutes with Elfrid Payton (ankle) getting hurt today. While Payton could not play for most of the second half, he was initially able to return after an ankle tweak in the first half. In other words, it doesn't sound serious, so Clark is only a speculative add in the deepest of leagues.
Cheick Diallo behind Jah Okafor: The Pelicans were blown out, so the 11 minutes are misleading due to garbage time. Jahlil Okafor is ahead of Diallo for now.

Moe Harkless (knee soreness) will not return: Not good. That's his bad knee and it keeps flaring up on him. Considering how long he's been dealing with this issue, it might make some sense for the Blazers to shut him down until he gets right. Jake Layman and Evan Turner could pick up some run, but there's not a fantasy pickup here.

Kyrie Irving scores just three points vs. DET: It's the lowest scoring game with at least 20 minutes in his entire NBA career. Irving's dip in usage has been a trend all year, but only using seven possessions is a stunner tonight. Besides scoring, his stats are pretty much on par with the expectation, but Irving sitting at just 14.0 points per game is nowhere near even his biggest naysayers had him. He is a buy-low candidate, but the odds look to be against him in hitting early-round value this season.

Daniel Theis scores 17 points in easy win: His foot sprain clearly didn't bother him, but he did suffer a heel injury and didn't talk to the media. Theis was setting a lot of screens up high in the second unit, and his guards set him up with great looks all over the court. Aron Baynes (hamstring) could miss more time, but Theis is more of a deep-league target of a DFS punt. Garbage time helped him tonight, too.

Jaylen Brown scores 19 points vs. Pistons: Finally. Brown was a shell of himself on offense before today, and a hot start helped him carry the first unit offensively. With Jayson Tatum making a leap, there won't be many shots to go around in this offense and Brown has been subpar in percentages without really anything to hang his hat on in the box scores, so he's probably not worth holding in shallower leagues.

Gordon Hayward scores 15 in 24 minutes: It was his most efficient shooting game from the floor, and it was encouraging to see coach Brad Stevens kept Hayward in there until the middle of the fourth with the Celtics up about 25 to get him close to his prescribed 25 minutes. The Celtics continue to get him around 25 minutes per game and there's no word that he'll have that limit elevated any time soon.

Terry Rozier scores 14 points in 25 minutes: This was slightly aided by garbage time, but Rozier had a strong first half to help the Celtics pull away. The Boston second unit has been outstanding this year with Rozier being among the league leaders in defensive rating. Kyrie Irving just hasn't looked like himself, so maybe Rozier can find a path to more minutes. Plus, Boston blowing people out is good for his value.

Blake Griffin makes 2-of-13 from the field: As it turns, he wasn't going to shoot 65.2% from deep like he had in the first four. The Celtics defended Griffin tighter on the wing and it limited him from getting better looks off screens, and they also kept him from getting to the line with just four attempts. His 33.8 points per game was not sustainable, but Griffin could score in the upper 20s and should be in line for a big season under coach Dwane Casey.

Reggie Bullock struggles again: Maybe this shoulder thing is bothering him. He's having a rough start to the year, but it's not like anyone else is stepping up while Bullock struggles. He should continue to see big minutes and the loss of Luke Kennard (shoulder) secures his role even more. That said, if you want to drop Bullock because of his poor play, it's not like people in your 12-team league are going to be dropping any decent FAAB or a high waiver on him.

Andre Drummond only has eight boards: It's the first time he failed to get a double-double and coach Dwane Casey may have kept Drummond in there in garbage time to avoid snapping his streak. Before tonight, Drummond was just a shade under 27% in total rebounding rate and he had 17.8 boards per game over the first four, so he'll likely rebound against Boston again on Tuesday.

Stanley Johnson scores 16 points: Before today, things couldn't have gone much worse for Johnson in the first three, making just 30.4 percent from the field. Even in what has been his best game of the year in this bad loss, it's not like this will move the needle on him as a pickup in fantasy. If he has 2-3 more games like this in the next week, maybe Johnson can garner the attention of fantasy owners.
Giannis Antetokounmpo (head) returns to game: He was only in the locker room for a few minutes so hopefully he's fine going forward.
Giannis Antetokounmpo (head) leaves game: He took a nice shot from Gordon and was examined by the training staff. We'll update you as soon as we know more.

Elfrid Payton (ankle) will not return vs. UTA: This is likely from his injury in the first half and it may have swelled up at half. In case you missed it, he slipped when he was guarding Ricky Rubio and had a fall after that. Payton was able to get back on offense and he did return, so it likely isn't serious. While he's out, we'll see more Ian Clark while Frank Jackson also got his first rotation minutes tonight. Payton finished with two rebounds, four assists and two turnovers in 16 minutes.

Ball, Hart, LeBron, Kuzma, McGee will start: Coach Luke Walton likes the idea of splitting up LeBron and Rondo, which is great for Lonzo. Starting is great for his fantasy value, as it should earn him more playing time.

Canaan, Jackson, Ariza, Ryno, Ayton starting: Anderson was probable with a hip issue, but he should see more minutes with Josh Jackson shifting to guard. Still, Anderson isn't part of the long-term plans and likely won't get many shots unless he's hot.
Elfrid Payton returns to game in 2nd quarter: He went to the locker room and was stretching his leg on the bench after that, so it's likely another cramping issue for the second night in a row.

Elfrid Payton goes to the locker room: He did have a cramping issue yesterday and it could be that again. Payton was guarding Ricky Rubio had slipped on a step, and then he fell under the basket. He jogged slowly to get to the offensive side of the floor, then checked out and went to the locker room. If he can't return, we'll see more Ian Clark to play off the ball.

Joel Embiid (ankle) will play Saturday night: Embiid was a game-time decision after rolling his ankle in practice on Friday. He warmed up and got the go-ahead to be able to play. Coach Brett Brown was optimistic in his pregame press conference and also said he thought Embiid's X-rays were negative. There's no word on whether or not he'll be limited, but hopefully he can be effective either way.

Devin Booker won't play, doing light shooting: He had a sleeve on his left leg and may have done some other on-court work before this game. Booker is only day-to-day after his Wednesday hammy pull and hopefully he can make it back out there next week. Josh Jackson should get the start and would see huge minutes while one of the rookie PGs gets some burn.

Reggie Bullock will start against Boston: He was called probable for this shoulder issue, but he should be ready to roll for a full workload. With Luke Kennard out, Bullock should see extra minutes with plenty of treys, so he's worth a look in standard leagues.
Jakob Poeltl to the bench: He is not on coach Gregg Popovich's good side and it may take time for him to get the system down. Leave Poeltl on the wire.

Rudy Gay coming off the bench on Saturday: He's started in the first four games of the season, so it's likely a matchup move against the up-tempo Lakers. Assuming the Spurs aren't up to something, Gay should still see minutes in the 24-28 range in a fantasy-friendly matchup

Dante Cunningham in the starting lineup: He's been moving in and out of the starting lineup, but Cunningham managed just three points in 29 minutes in his start on Monday. He's only a tourney DFS play in hopes he can rack up boards or make easy shots.

Davis Bertans, Dante Cunningham start vs. LAL: Bertans and Cunningham will be joined by Bryn Forbes, DeMar DeRozan, and LaMarcus Aldridge in the starting unit. Coach Gregg Popovich hasn't been shy with switching up his starting lineup so far this season and tonight is no exception with Rudy Gay moving to the bench. Bertans doesn't have much fantasy value, outside of 3-pointers, but makes for an interesting DFS punt tonight.

Deandre Ayton (ankle) will play on Saturday: He was called probable from some ankle soreness, which he suffered in practice a week ago. Ayton didn't look hobbled against the Lakers on Wednesday with a 22-point gem, so expect him to be a full go as he makes a case for Rookie of the Year.

Marc Gasol will play on Saturday night: He suffered what looked to be a scary injury in Sacramento, but he won't need to miss a whole game here. Gasol may have this issue pop up down the line, but he gets a great matchup against the Suns with a less than 100% Deandre Ayton.

Dillon Brooks will come off the bench: Kyle Anderson will remain in the starting lineup and Brooks will likely back him up given the lack of depth at forward today. Brooks won't get enough volume to roster in most fantasy formats.

Derrick Jones Jr. (foot) to play vs. Blazers: He has been playing some power forward this season, so his return could push Kelly Olynyk back to the bench. Jones Jr. has shown flashes in the young season, but he's been foul prone and likely won't do enough to matter in most leagues.

Wayne Ellington will play on Saturday: It'll be his season debut from this nagging issue that has bothered him since the start of camp. Ellington may not have a clear path to big minutes because of Rodney McGruder's strong start, so leave him on the wire.

Julius Randle in the starting lineup for AD: Randle was probable, but he has been probable before with his plantar fascia injury. With AD out, Randle should be asked to create offense out of the post, but the bad news is he gets Rudy Gobert down on the block. Still, he should see more run and could have an increased usage rate to up his ceiling in DFS.

Anthony Davis (elbow) will not play Saturday: Wow. Davis suffered the injury on Friday night and it didn't bother him until it flared up on him after the game. It is to his shooting elbow, so perhaps that is a factor in keeping AD out against one of the better teams in the West. The Pelicans play again in Denver, so consider The Brow questionable for that one. With him out, the Pelicans will move Julius Randle into the starting lineup next to Nikola Mirotic while Cheick Diallo or Jahlil Okafor could back them up.

Justise Winslow will play on Saturday: Winslow had a setback to his hammy this week and it cost him more time, so the Heat will undoubtedly take it easy on him. With Rodney McGruder playing lights out, Winslow may not get to 20 minutes in his return.

Russ Westbrook (shoulder) questionable Sunday: He did not practice today due to the soreness in his shoulder, and the Thunder will not have a shootaround tomorrow. That means Westbrook is likely headed for a game-time decision for the 7:00 EDT start time. If he can't go , Dennis Schroder would likely start while Hamidou Diallo could see more run after an impressive week.

Tony Parker (rest) will not play vs. 76ers: He did suffer a minor hand injury on Friday, but the team says it's rest in a back-to-back set. Parker lit it up in that win over the Bulls with 18 points, so there will be some opportunity for the Hornets guards. Devonte Graham could get his first chance at rotation minutes, or maybe Malik Monk slots in as a backup PG because he handles the ball for the second unit quite a bit. This news also helps out Jeremy Lamb and Nicolas Batum.

Kevin Love (foot) out; Sam Dekker starting: That makes it two games in a row for Love with his foot soreness. The Cavs are the only 0-5 team in the NBA and it may not be long before they start to tank it up. With Love out, that'll add more volume to the other scorers on the team, so maybe Rodney Hood, Jordan Clarkson, Collin Sexton, Larry Nance and J.R. Smith could have more shots. Love's fantasy outlook isn't the best right now.

Sam Dekker getting the starting: The Cavs aren't going to start Channing Frye again and maybe they even rest him. Neither Dekker or Frye are reliable fantasy plays unless you're looking for a tourney punt in DFS, but Larry Nance could benefit even though he's played center.

Joel Embiid (ankle) will be a game-time call: He's going on the court at around the time of this news to warmup for the game tonight, so we should get an update at around 6:30 EDT. Embiid rolled his ankle at practice on Friday and there's not much known on the severity of his ailment. If he can't go, Amir Johnson would likely get the start while Jonah Bolden should see minutes. Ben Simmons and the whole rotation would have to shoot more to replace The Process' 31.7 usage rate, too.

Daniel Theis (foot sprain) available to play: No word on if he will suit up, but he has a good chance with Aron Baynes (hamstring) not out there for this one. Theis isn't worth owning in most leagues while Al Horford is healthy.

Anthony Davis (elbow) is a game-time call: Coach Alvin Gentry said he won't know AD's availability for tonight until after warmups, so we likely won't have much time before the 7:00 EDT tip time. Davis did hurt his elbow last night, but it didn't start to flare up until after he left the arena. If he can't go, Julius Randle and Nikola Mirotic would get a few more minutes while Cheick Diallo could get into the rotation. There would be more shots for Jrue Holiday and basically the entire rotation, too.

Markieff Morris (illness) misses practice: He looked fine on Friday in 37 minutes against the Kings with 13 points and he picked up a tech for getting in Buddy Hield's face, so maybe this is the first day he's dealing with the illness. The Wizards are in Los Angeles for Sunday night against the Clippers, so he could be a game-time decision. If he can't go, Jeff Green and Kelly Oubre would get more run.

Rodions Kurucs (ankle) still out: His ankle tweak from last weekend will now hold him out for at least a week. Kuruc had a terrific preseason, but it may be tough for him to get minutes now that Rondae Hollis-Jefferson is back.

Rajon Rondo expected to come off bench: With Lonzo Ball staying the starting lineup, it should be Rajon Rondo shifting to a bench role. Rondo is back after a three-game absence today and his minutes likely take a hit with this news, but the pace of the Lakers may be enough to buoy his value in some formats.

ESPN: Lonzo Ball to remain in starting lineup: The Lakers played their best two games of the season as they earned a win in Phoenix and beating the Nuggets at Staples Center, so coach Luke Walton will carry that momentum even with Rajon Rondo returning from his suspension. Ball's defense was outstanding and his transition game fits the identity of the team. This is terrific news for his fantasy value and he should see minutes next to Rondo, as well.

Anthony Davis (elbow) questionable vs. Utah: The Pelicans put out an injury report earlier today, but they just added AD to this new one in the afternoon. Davis did finish his game on Friday and played 38 minutes, but he had his worst shooting game of the season with a 6-of-19 shooting line. If this shooting-elbow problem is still bothering him, maybe the Pelicans sit him in a back-to-back set. If he can't go, there will be plenty of shots to go around while Nikola Mirotic and Julius Randle have their minutes extended. We would likely see some Cheick Diallo, as well.

Luc Mbah a Moute (knee) questionable Sunday: Mbah a Moute did not play against the Rockets on Friday due to the knee injury. He is averaging just 5.0 points and 1.8 rebounds in 15.3 minutes this season, so he should be left on waivers in all fantasy leagues. Montrezl Harrell has been on fire of late. Over the Clippers last three games, Harrell is averaging 19.7 points, 7.3 rebounds, 1.7 steals and 2.3 blocks in 24.9 minutes. He should see again plenty of playing time on Sunday if Mbah a Moute is ruled out. Mike Scott would also play increased minutes.

James Johnson (groin) ruled out Saturday: Johnson has been practicing with the team this week, but has not yet been cleared to make his season debut. JJ played through a nagging hernia injury in 2017-18, and it was partly responsible for his dip in production. He averaged 10.9 points and 4.8 rebounds and shot 30.8 percent on 3-pointers last season. Thus, it could be that Miami is erring on the side of caution and waiting until he is fully healed before allowing him to play in a game.

Russell Westbrook (shoulder) doesn't practice: Westbrook missed the first two games of the season while recovering from knee surgery, but has looked healthy in each of OKC's last two contests. He tallied 13 points, 15 rebounds, eight assists and five turnovers in 32 minutes on Thursday night vs. Boston. It's unknown if Russ injured his shoulder in that game or in practice on Friday. Also, Donovan did not specify which shoulder Westbrook injured. If Russ is ruled out Sunday, Dennis Schroder would draw the start at PG and would be a popular DFS target.

Josh Jackson likely to start on Saturday: Jackson has struggled mightily this season. Over the Suns last three games, Jackson is averaging 5.0 points, 1.7 rebounds, 2.3 assists and 3.0 turnovers, while shooting just 27.3 percent from the floor, 20 percent from 3-point territory and 33.3 percent from the free-throw line. He did average 15/5/2 in the 35 games he started last season, so hopefully, he snaps out of his slump on Saturday.

Ryan Anderson (hip) upgraded to qustionable: Anderson is expected to suit up on Saturday, but he has been inefficient and ineffective this season. He is currently averaging just 5.5 points and 3.5 rebounds in 21.5 minutes, while shooting a putrid 36.0 percent from the floor and 20 percent from downtown.

Deandre Ayton (ankle) upgraded to probable: Ayton tweaked his ankle last week, but it has not been an issue for him. He tallied 22 points, 11 rebounds, three assists and three blocks on Wednesday. On the season, he is averaging 16.3 points (on 62.8 percent shooting), 10.8 boards and 3.8 assists. With Devin Booker (hamstring) sidelined on Saturday, Ayton should see even more touches on the offensive end and could post his highest usage rate of the season.

Elfrid Payton (leg) not on injury report: Payton was cramping up at the end of Friday's game vs. Brooklyn, but it is clearly just a minor issue. He will be ready to rock Saturday vs. the Jazz. Elf is off to an excellent start this season, averaging 14.5 points, 7.0 rebounds and 7.0 assists.

Darius Miller (quad) ruled out Saturday: Miller injured his quad Friday night in the Pelicans victory over the Nets and was unable to return to the contest. On the season, he is averaging 3.8 points and 1.5 assists in 15.0 minutes. Wes Johnson and Solomon Hill should see an uptick in minutes with Miller sidelined.

Julius Randle (foot) probable Saturday: Randle is dealing with plantar fasciitis in his left foot but it hasn't slowed him down. He scored 14 points with seven rebounds, three assists, one steal, two blocks and two turnovers in 23 minutes on Friday night. For the season, he is averaging 17.5 points, 8.5 rebounds, and a career-high 1.0 treys in 23.3 minutes.

Derrick Jones Jr. (foot) still probable Sat: Jones did not play Wednesday vs. the Knicks but is expected to return to action on Saturday. However, both Justise Winslow (sore right hamstring) and Wayne Ellington (ankle) are also probable for this contest. As a result, Jones will likely see his playing time reduced significantly going forward.

Justise Winslow (hamstring) remains probable: Derrick Jones Jr., Wayne Ellington and Winslow all remain probable for Saturday's contest. Winslow has yet to make his 2018-19 debut. In 2017-18, he averaged 7.8 points, 5.4 rebounds, and 2.2 assists. He is not worth rostering in most fantasy formats.

Sam Dekker may start Saturday if Love out: Channing Frye started Thursday in place of Love on Thursday and tallied five points and four rebounds in 21 minutes. Larry Nance logged 28 minutes off the bench and finished with 11 points, six rebounds, five assists and three steals. Dekker did not play Thursday. He is averaging 5.0 points and 3.3 rebounds in 10.8 minutes over his four appearances this season.

Daniel Theis (foot) questionable Saturday: Theis has appeared in four of the Celtics five games this season and is averaging 3.3 points and 2.3 rebounds in 10.5 minutes. Aron Baynes (hamstring) has already been ruled out, so the C's may be a bit shorthanded up front. If Theis is unable to play, Marcus Morris and Guerschon Yabusele would soak up additional minutes.

Aron Baynes (hamstring) ruled out Saturday: Coach Brad Stevens said the team is holding out Baynes just to be conservative. Baynes said he does not feel hamstring pain, stating: 'If it was playoff time there would be no doubt.' The Celtics next game is Tuesday in Boston, and it would appear Baynes has a good chance to suit up for that contest. Daniel Theis (foot) is questionable for Saturday. If he is unable to play, Guerschon Yabusele would likely see an uptick in minutes. Marcus Morris will also log additional playing time Saturday.

Elfrid Payton says he had cramping in leg: Payton needed to be attended to by trainers as he sat on the court in the fourth quarter on Friday night, but it seemed evident that it as only a cramp issue. Elfrid Payton scored 17 points with five rebounds, six assists and one 3-pointer in 31 minutes vs. the Nets and will look to continue the hot start to his season Saturday night.

Devin Harris (hamstring) making progress: Harris hasn't played since the season opener, but is headed in the right direction. 'He's doing well,' Carlisle said. 'He's getting better gradually every day. I don't know when he'll play. It might be sooner than I thought. I think Sunday is very doubtful, but I just don't know. The injury wasn't a serious injury. Hey, when you're 35, you know your body and you got to step back and get treatment for a while until you don't feel it anymore. That's what we went through with Harrison. I'm hopeful it's sooner than later.' Even when fully healthy, Harris is not on the fantasy radar.

John Wall and Bradley Beal call out teammates: The Wiz dropped to 1-4 on the season Friday night and tension appears to be building in the locker room. 'Weve got guys thats worried about whos getting shots. You should never worry about that,' said Wall. Brad Beal also had some harsh comments: 'Sometimes, we have our own agendas on the floor, whether its complaining about shots, complaining about playing time, complaining about whatever it may be.' Neither player mentioned Otto Porter by name, but coach Scott Brooks did, saying Porter 'cant worry about' his shots. Yikes. The Wizards next game is Sunday vs. the Clippers.

Kevin Love (foot) questionable for Saturday: Love missed multiple preseason games due to lingering soreness in his left foot and then, after struggling through the first four games of the regular season, he was ruled out of Thursday's contest vs. Detroit. Channing Frye started Thursday and tallied five points and four rebounds in 21 minutes. Larry Nance logged 28 minutes off the bench and finished with 11 points, six rebounds, five assists and three steals. Nance is worth DFS consideration if Love is ruled out Saturday.

Reggie Bullock (shoulder) probable Saturday: Bullock had a dud on Thursday night (five points on 2-of-10 shooting) but was averaging 16.5 points over his first two games of the year. It seems a slight shoulder injury may have been part of the reason. Nonetheless, With Luke Kennard (shoulder) sidelined and Stanley Johnson playing poorly, Bullock is locked into heavy minutes and should continue to provide value in deep leagues.

Dennis Smith Jr. (ankle) plans to play Sunday: Smith tweaked his ankle in Wednesday's game vs. Atlanta and played with a noticeable limp in that contest. He was expected to suit up Friday vs. the Raptors but was ruled out. Smith warmed up prior to the game, but said his ankle didn't feel right. We'll consider him questionable for now, and should expect an update after Sunday morning's shootaround.

Buddy Hield scores 22 points on 8-of-17 FGs: This was on the heels of a 23-point effort on Wednesday, so Hield is heating up. He's very efficient for a SG and was hitting 50.7 from the field prior to Friday, and he kept that trend going with 8-of-17 shots tonight. He has a shot at mid-round value this season, especially if he can get his steals up (he only has one through six games).

De'Aaron Fox scores 18 points in win: It was quite a night for Fox with some sound defense and several highlights which included a crossover that put Austin Rivers on skates. His turnovers and FT% haven't improved since his rookie season just yet, but his FG% has gone up considerably -- he hit 7-of-14 shots tonight and is now hitting 47.4% on the season compared to 41.2% as a rookie.

Nemanja Bjelica drops 26 points vs. Wizards: He finished four points away from his career-high (30), and this was his third career game with 20+ points. Bjelica added 12 rebounds to complete his double-double with three assists, one steal, one block and six triples in 36 minutes. He was worth owning before this explosion and is now sitting inside the top-25 for 9-category rankings. Temper your expectations though, as the Kings will eventually take a longer look at their younger guys.

Iman Shumpert plays 17 minutes in return: He was actually playing pretty well before the injury, but he's never been a reliable fantasy contributor and his rest-of-season outlook is pretty bleak on such a young roster.

Jeff Green scores 13 points vs. Kings: He played 27 minutes and closed this game alongside Kelly Oubre with Otto Porter struggling, hitting 5-of-8 shots and a pair of free throws. The Wizards are shorthanded right now and coach Scott Brooks has been using smaller lineups, so Green has seen a nice bump in value. He has played 24 or more minutes in four out of five games, but he's still just a deep-league asset for now.

Kelly Oubre scores 22 points vs. Kings: With Otto Porter struggling again, coach Scott Brooks turned to Oubre and Jeff Green. Oubre added nine rebounds, two assists, one steal, one block and five 3-pointers, and he's now played 29 or more minutes in three straight with averages of 20.3 points, 6.3 rebounds and 3.7 triples in that span. Oubre's value could trend down if Porter figures things out or when Dwight Howard (back) returns, but he has to be owned right now.

Otto Porter benched down the stretch: He played 22 minutes and has now seen less than 25 minutes of action in three out of five games. Kelly Oubre had the hot hand with 22 points and has been impressive with three straight games of 17+ points, and coach Scott Brooks has been rolling with Jeff Green an awful lot too. Porter's value is too low to trade right now, so fantasy owners just have to hope that he turns things around soon.

Ian Mahinmi (back) plays 19 minutes in loss: The Wizards really like their small-ball lineup with Markieff Morris at the five, so Mahinmi isn't going to get much run even with Dwight Howard (back) out. He can be left on the wire pretty much everywhere.

Bradley Beal scores 21 points in loss: This was his second game of the season with at least 39 minutes and his third with at least 35. This was Beal's first bad shooting performance of the season, as he hit just 6-of-19 shots after hitting 50.6% in his previous for games. He was a true-game time call tonight, so maybe the injury held him back a bit. He's a top-5 fantasy SG and should get back on track vs. the Clippers on Sunday.

John Wall scores 26, Wizards fall to 1-4: It still wasn't enough though, as the Wizards imploded late and fell to 1-4 on the season. He came into tonight's game shooting 41.3% from the field and 68.4% from the line, but it was never a concern for him. 'It takes time. It is what it is. I know Im putting in all the work in and preparing myself for every game,' Wall said. 'Youre not going to make every shot. You just got to go there and be confident.' We'll see if Wall and the Wizards can get a result in Los Angeles vs. the Clippers on Sunday, but a lot of Washington fans are already panicking.

John Henson scores nine points vs. Wolves: He's playing just above 17.0 minutes per game on the season and won't have consistent value while Brook Lopez is healthy. On a side note, it's nice to see Henson expanding his range, as he's now shooting 5-of-11 from beyond the arc on the season. This makes him even more intriguing if Lopez ever picked up an injury.

Eric Bledsoe scores six points in blowout: He played just 21 minutes because of the blowout, finishing with a +21 in his limited action. Even with this dud factored in, Bledsoe is cruising with top-35 value in standard leagues and comfortably beating his ADP.

Giannis Antetokounmpo scores 15 points: The Wolves were in shambles and the Bucks built a 30-point lead entering the fourth quarter, so Giannis took an early seat after 23 minutes. His efficiency hasn't been the best so far in the young season, but his counting stats are off the charts once again, especially his rebounding -- he's posting a career-high 20.5 rebounding percentage, up from 14.1% last season. It's scary how good this guy could be.
Matthew Dellavedova scores six points: He got some burn in garbage time with the game well out of reach. If Delly is on your fantasy team, you can log off until next season.

Thon Maker makes season debut: He cleaned up in garbage time with the Bucks up by 30 points entering the fourth quarter. Maker is comfortably behind Brook Lopez and John Henson and there's no indication that that will change any time soon. We're taking him off the injury report after a knee issue limited him for a couple weeks.

Karl-Anthony Towns scores 16 in ugly loss: These are dark days for KAT's owners, and he didn't even touch the floor in the fourth with Minnesota trailing by 30. Outside of blocks and FT%, his numbers are way down across the board. His fantasy owners just need to hang in there and hope KAT's situation improves when Jimmy Butler is inevitably traded.

Anthony Davis with 18-14, 4 steals, 5 blocks: He became the 94th player to join the NBA's 1,000 blocks club in this win, and AD has the last two performances in the NBA of at least 18 points, 14 rebounds, four steals and five blocks because of course he does. Yeah, AD is scoring a bunch at 27.3 points per game with 13.3 boards to go with it, but his 3.8 blocks and 2.5 steals are what really separates him from the bunch. If you passed on AD and he stays healthy, it's going to sting all season when you look at his stat lines.

Jeff Teague held to four points in loss: He missed all five of his 3-pointers and couldn't salvage his line with four assists and two rebounds. Teague, Karl-Anthony Towns, Jimmy Butler and Josh Okogie all had a +/- rating of -23 or worse, and they scored a combined 28 points. The Wolves are a mess right now, but Teague's owners shouldn't overreact.

Jrue Holiday scores season-high 26 points: It was only a matter of time before he busted out of his three-game slump to start the year. Holiday also hit a game-winning jumper to keep the Pelicans as the only undefeated team in the West. The Pelicans continue to push the pace and that will set up a lot of easy transition buckets for Holiday, so expect him to be a helpful contributor in FG%. If you bought low on him this week, well done.

Jimmy Butler (illness) held to four points: He probably should've sat this one out, but as you know, that's not his thing. The trade rumors have started to intensify again, and coach Tom Thibodeau addressed them at the morning shootaround. 'You just got to do what's right,' Thibs said. 'To me, it's like, if something is a good deal and you think you're getting good value, you have to do what's right for the franchise.' A trade is more likely to go down when Marquese Chriss and Brandon Knight are eligible to be moved on Oct. 31, but you never know in the NBA.

Julius Randles scores 14 points vs. Nets: He continues to just set up shop in the paint and he's meshed nicely with Anthony Davis, as well. Randle is dealing with a minor plantar fascia issue and he was probable today, so hopefully things don't get worse for him.

Elfrid Payton has cramps late: He did suffer what looks to be a minor leg injury at the end of the game, but  after the game he said it was just cramps. Payton has done well in this up-tempo offense and looks like a solid value from drafts.

D'Angelo Russell drops 24 with costly late TO: Things were going about as well as they could have, but Russell had a careless turnover with 7.5 seconds left to give the Pelicans the ball back and allow Jrue Holiday to win the game on the next possession. Russell has been hot for two games in a row now, and coach Kenny Atkinson likely won't punish him for just a lapse of judgment. He's trending up after a slow start.

Caris LeVet scores 21 points in 31 minutes: The efficiency was not there, but Jrue Holiday has held countless All-Star guards in check. LeVert continues to show his grasp of the offense, his usage rate remains high, and he's really grown as a distributor to go with his explosive scoring style. While he has taken a step back after those off-the-charts two games to start, LeVert is still on track to be one of the best values on draft day.

Danny Green stays hot w/ 15 points, four 3s: He has found the form that made him a fantasy star back in 2014-15. Green is churning out top-40 value in 9-category leagues right now because of his 3-pointers (3.0), steals (1.0) and blocks (1.2), all while leading the Raptors in net rating (+19.8). He was flying off the waiver wire last week, but he's more than likely long gone in competitive leagues.

Jarrett Allen fills the stat sheet vs. AD: The scoring wasn't there, but Allen had one of his better games of the season from a defensive standpoint. Plus, only two fouls against Anthony Davis while keeping AD in check overall. In fact, all 28 of Allen's minutes came against AD and The Brow made just 5-of-18 from the field. Plus, the dimes and steals are showing up for Allen, so he'll be just fine as a breakout candidate.

Pascal Siakam plays 37 minutes in win: He hit 4-of-8 shots and a pair of free throws, but missed his two 3-point attempts. The Raptors were missing three guys tonight including OG Anunoby (personal), so we can't read too much into the spike in minutes -- he was averaging 20.6 minutes per game before Friday. He is second on the Raptors in net rating (+17.8) and will earn an expanded role if he keeps it up, so he's a decent stash at the end of standard-league rosters.

Rondae Hollis-Jefferson  scores just four: The Nets went super small for long stretches in this game and coach Kenny Atkinson isn't quite ready to take the limits off Hollis-Jefferson. It should happen in the near future, so his owners should be hanging in there in all formats.

Kyle Lowry scores 20 w/ 12 assists in win: He now has 10+ assists in four straight games for the first time in his career and has led the Raptors to their first 6-0 start in franchise history. He's cruising right now and has been the 7th best player in 9-category leagues. He'll draw a matchup with Eric Bledsoe and the Bucks on Monday.

Shabazz Napier scores 16 points: The Nets went super small again as Napier got hot in the second half, but both D'Angelo Russell and Caris LeVert were back to close. Napier is going to be too inconsistent to own in most leagues.

Montrezl Harrell scores career-high 30 points: Revenge game? In Sunday's win over the Rockets, Harrell said revenge wasn't a factor, but could've fooled us with this one and a 17-point gem on Sunday as the Clippers won both. For tonight, Harrell lived in the paint and cleaned up at the line, making 14-of-15 from the stripe. Harrell had 21 and five at the end of the third thanks to playing the final 17 minutes in the first half and just taking over to close the third. He may not start, but there's no way Harrell can remain on the waiver wire with now three straight outstanding games.

Pat Beverley gets 17 minutes: Foul trouble got him and the flow of the game kept him out. Shai Gilgeous-Alexander hasn't looked like a rookie on either end and he's already shown he can switch in the NBA's PNR-happy style, so Beverley may need a trade to revive his fantasy value.

Jonas Valanciunas scores 17 points in start: He was back in the starting lineup to match up with DeAndre Jordan, one of the last few non-shooting bigs in the NBA. 'Dying,' J-Val said of centers who can't shoot. 'The big guy's dying.' For context, that's one of the reasons why J-Val has spent so much time trying to expand his range. J-Val is only averaging 20.3 minutes as a starter compared to 18.0 minutes as a reserve, so the starting designation doesn't change his value too much. He will likely be back on the bench for Monday's matchup vs. Brook Lopez and the Bucks, but then back in the first unit for Tuesday's game vs. Joel Embiid's 76ers.
Marcin Gortat doesn't score: Montrezl Harrell may not start, but it's abundantly clear he is the man. Drop Gortat, assuming you haven't already.

SGA scores 10 in 31 minutes: The three-guard lineups were out in force today. Gilgeous-Alexander has likely already has closed the gap on Pat Beverley, and finding minutes at the three adds to his floor in most matchups. It's still going to take some times before you're really excited about putting SGA in your lineup, but you're going to have to wait because there will be a long line to put a claim in on him if he's dropped.
