Dorian Finney-Smith comes off the bench: Harrison Barnes was limited to 28 minutes, but should be over 30+ soon. DFS is an easy cut in deeper leagues and is probably looking at minutes in the teens going forward.

Milos Teodosic makes his debut: He was in there for the first half as coach Doc Rivers mixed it up. It was a surprise to see him in there as the Clippers went heavy with three-guard lineups. If Luc Mbah a Moute (knee) is out, maybe Milos will stay in the rotation, but this could've been about the matchup against the smaller Rockets lineups.

Jalen Brunson scores eight points in start: It wasn't pretty and he was scoreless in the first half, but Brunson did settle into his role down the stretch. He finished 3-of-11 from the field and turned the ball over twice. It doesn't sound like Dennis Smith Jr.'s ankle injury is serious and he was a late scratch tonight, so there's no need to grab Brunson in most leagues. When Dallas is healthy, the rookie is still behind both DSJ and J.J. Barea, but coach Rick Carlisle wanted to keep his second unit together tonight.

Lou Wiliams scores 23 points in 26 minutes: He looked like he would've easily hit 30 after he had 19 in the first half, but the Clippers ran away from the Rockets and they didn't need Williams down the stretch. Before the game, coach Doc Rivers said he wants Lou to drive more, so Williams could get back to his high-scoring ways we saw last season.

Harrison Barnes scores 14 points in return: Some rust is to be expected after a lengthy absence, but Barnes was moving well and should be back over 30+ minutes in no time. He's been the Mavs primary go-to scorer the last two seasons and he doesn't think that will change with a stronger supporting cast around him. 'My job is to go out there and be aggressive offensively and defensively,' Barnes said. 'I pretty much am used to adapting, so I dont see my role changing too much.' Even with Luka Doncic around, Barnes has a clear path to mid-round value.

DeAndre Jordan scores 18 w/ 15 rebounds: He was 5-of-10 from the field and has suddenly turned into Dirk Nowitzki from the line this season -- he hit 8-of-9 free throws and is now shooting 84.6% on the season (22-of-26). That would obliterate his previous career-high of 58%, so it might be a little foolish to expect this pace the rest of the way. He still deserves a ton of credit for turning things around in his age-30 season and he's been awesome for the Mavs so far.

Michael Carter-WIlliams scores 10: He played the last six minutes of garbage time to boost his stats slightly. He's pretty much unaffected by the James Harden injury because Carter-Williams is functionally a wing in this rotation. Leave him on the wire in most leagues

Eric Gordon struggles vs. Clippers: The first unit came out flat and Gordon couldn't do anything in his minutes staggered away from Chris Paul, making 3-of-14 from the field. He'll get another chance to produce without James Harden (hamstring) in the mix, so expect a much better game on Tuesday.

Luka Doncic scores 22 points in loss to TOR: People were actually worried that Doncic's offense wouldn't translate because he's not the greatest athlete, but he just dropped 22 points with the NBA's best defender in Kawhi Leonard guarding him. Doncic has now scored 19+ points in four out of five games, and it was a relief to see him knock down all four of his free throws tonight after shooting 61.9% from the line prior to Friday. He'll get the Jazz on Sunday in Dallas.

Gerald Green scores 19 points vs. Clips: He probably likes garbage time more than Christmas with 10 points in the fourth. Green will have another chance to produce with James Harden (hamstring) out at least one more, but this 19-point game probably wouldn't have got your attention had it been a close contest.

Frank Ntilikina scores 17 in start at PG: Things were going well for the Knicks, then the fourth quarter happened when they were outscored 47-16. Ntilikina had some trouble on Steph Curry, but this was a win for Ntilikina's outlook. Before the game, coach David Fizdale explained himself on why he was starting Franky Smokes. 'I want to see him in a lot of different capacities and see which one fits best, which one he might impact winning the best at,' Fizdale said. He also said he doesn't want to put a cap on his guard and he's going to take his time. There will be some ups and downs for the raw French guard, but he could still be worth a look if you're looking for a mystery box to add to your roster.

Draymond Green scores 18 vs. Knicks: That's more like it. Green was only shooting 37.9% from the field and 66.7% from the line prior to Friday, so it was nice to see improvement there (7-of-8 FGs, 2-of-2 FTs). His turnovers (4) are still an issue, but with Green you just have to take the good with the bad. He'll have another favorable matchup vs. the Nets on Sunday.

Mitchell Robinson plays 29 minutes in start: The Knicks were up in the early fourth, so this wasn't garbage time despite the 28-point loss. He only committed two fouls and didn't look out of place against the NBA's best team. The Knicks have said they wanted to get Robinson some time in the G League to get him going, but maybe they'll change course given his performance in a start. Odds are he will be a headache to own in the near future, so he's more of a stash in weekly leagues or if adding him now doesn't hurt you.

Damyean Dotson plays well in start: He's clearly the guy that has stepped in to Kevin Knox's role while the rookie recovers from an ankle injury. Coach David Fizdale's rotation is a complete mess right now, so it's tough to tell how long Dotson will be the guy. He's more of a deep-league pickup because he'll lose run when Knox returns next month.

Stephen Curry scores 29 points vs. Knicks: According to Warriors PR, his six-game streak with at least five 3-pointers is the longest such streak ever to begin a season. He hit 10-of-18 shots and 3-of-3 free throws, and he was well on his way to a monster night before Kevin Durant took over late with 25 of his 41 points in the fourth quarter. Curry is second to only Anthony Davis in 9-category leagues right now and just needs to stay healthy.

Noah Vonleh scores seven points in start: He was in the mix to start at center over Mitchell Robinson, but it turns out he started next to him. Vonleh has played more center than power forward, and chances are he'll go back into that role the next time out. This is a very fluid situation, so most owners may want to steer clear until it's not so murky. He could emerge as a stash if the Knicks sell off players.

Klay Thompson's struggles continue: He hit just 6-of-18 shots and missed all four of his 3-pointers. He's been particularly bad from deep this season, hitting just 4-of-31 (12.9%) attempts through six games. The shot attempts are still there with at least 14 over his last four games, and it's just a matter of time before one of the NBA's best shooters gets back into a rhythm. There's some obvious buy-low appeal here.

Lance Thomas scores two off the bench: Coach David Fizdale has compared Thomas to Draymond Green, so it's a fun coincidence that he came off the bench in this one. Thomas doesn't offer enough fantasy upside when the Knicks can suit up at least eight guys.

Mario Hezonja scores six off bench: He was -16 in 18 minutes. His role hasn't really changed much since Kevin Knox (ankle) went down with Damyean Dotson firmly ahead of him right now. Hezonja should be dropped in most leagues and/or swapped for Dotson.

Kevin Durant scores 41 points in win at MSG: This game was tight entering the fourth, but KD blew the lid off the arena with 25 of his points in the quarter (a career-high for points in a quarter). There was a lot of attention on KD because the Knicks are making him their top priority in free agency next summer, and he obviously loves playing at MSG, calling it a 'playground with walls.' KD has said himself that he's not looking beyond 2018-19, so we won't read too much into any of the chatter. As for fantasy, KD has been unfair over his last two games, shooting a combined 30-of-42 from the field.

Enes Kanter comes off the bench: He may not have been happy about the move to the bench and tweeted out one period after the lineup was announced. Any OKC fan will tell you that Kanter has been run off the floor against the Warriors, so that could have been a factor for coach David Fizdale. Kanter will undoubtedly have strong games, but the Knicks looking to tank later in the year could be a potential pitfall to his fantasy value.

Bradley Beal (chest) will start against Kings: He was a game-time decision and the Wizards took this one right up until the lineups were announced. Beal did not shootaround in this game and it'll be interesting to see how this affects his shot or contact on drives. You're obviously starting him in all formats.

Trey Burke scores 15 points in 22 minutes: Frank Ntilikina was pretty solid as an offensive player in this game, so maybe the Knicks will want to look at him a little more in the first unit. Either way, Burke was only shooting 38.7% from the field before today and it looks like that stretch-run finish last season looks like a fluke. He's a drop in most standard formats.

Kemba Walker scores 30 points in 26 minutes: The Hornets are on a back-to-back set, so coach James Borrego didn't need to play his star point guard in the fourth quarter. Walker continues to control the flow of the offense and was among the league leaders with his 8.5 minutes in time of possession, and his usage rate may actually be able to hold around 30 -- he's at a 31.4 usage rate with a 64.0 TS%.  If you drafted him in the second round, it looks like you hit a home run. If you drafted him in the third, you may want to consider a tougher league.

Marvin Williams gets 17 minutes: The competition is getting intense at the four with Michael Kidd-Gilchrist and Miles Bridges coming for Marvin's minutes. Wiliams is looking like a drop in most leagues.

Tony Parker scores 18 points vs. Bulls: He did hurt his right hand at the end of the second quarter, but he came back and obviously looked fine.  Parker continues to see minutes next to Kemba Walker and he's adapted to his off-ball game quite well. Still, he's more of a 16-team player to own.

Willy not going to be freed: With Michael Kidd-Gilchrist almost locked in as a five at times, there just isn't enough of a chance for Hernangomez right now. Free Willy will have to come at some other point this season.

MKG continues to log minutes at C: The Hornets are really leaning on MKG at the five and that is likely going to continue regardless of matchup. Since the opener, coach James Borrego has wanted to play MKG at the five after its play in the fourth, so maybe Kidd-Gilchrist can get to 25 minutes. Still, he isn't much of a stat-stuffing forward, so he's not quite 12-team material.

Miles Bridges scores 15 points in 26 minutes: Here comes Bridges and this wasn't all about garbage time. He was the first sub off the bench and his energy is something that will get him on coach James Borrego's good side. The Hornets really like going small, which could be the move that gets Bridges minutes i the 20s. If your league is competitive with pickups, it's probably time to grab him in 12-team leagues.

Iman Shumpert 'intends to play' Friday: Barring a setback in warmups or some shadiness from the Kings, Shumpert will return from a one-game absence. He's averaging 22.0 minutes per game and only has value in very deep leagues for the time being.

Zach LaVine scores 20 points in 26 minutes: He faced some much tougher defense in this game, but still his efficiency wasn't too bad thanks to the treys. LaVine has always been capable of blowing by his perimeter defenders and his ability to finish has taken his game to another level. Garbage time was also a factor in the front end of a back-to-back set, so LaVine likely would've scored over 25 in a close game. He'll be just fine as one of the breakout scorers this season.

Wendell Carter Jr. scores seven with two BKs: He has been overmatched on defense, and he's committed at least three fouls in each game despite playing under 24 minutes per game. Still, the Bulls have made their move on the center spot with Robin Lopez getting DNP-CDs, so Carter should start to figure out how to defend the paint in the near future. He's a buy-low option and he also hit his first trey today.

Cameron Payne scores 15 points in loss: He was hot to start the game, but there was just too much Kemba Walker to take the Bulls out of this one. Payne has done more than enough to show he should deserve close to 30 minutes at the point-guard spot, and he's suddenly a capable shooter from deep -- probably not sustainable. Regardless, he should be owned in standard leagues with what should be at least four weeks of production with Kris Dunn (knee) on the sidelines.

Chandler Hutchison flops in start: He played the final seven minutes in garbage time, so disregard those 28 minutes. Hutchison had a bad airball on a trey from the wing and he wasn't very useful on defense either. The Bulls got destroyed in this game, so maybe Hutchison doesn't stick in the first unit for long. Leave him on the wire.

Cris Felicio gets 30 minutes thanks to G time: Although, this wasn't about garbage time with Wendell Carter Jr. getting into some foul trouble. Felicio looks to be locked in as the backup center and he should get minutes in the 20s as WJC figures out the nuances of playing center in the NBA. Felicio could be a DFS punt some games in bad matchups or a deep-league option.

Jabari Parker scores 19 points off the bench: Coach Fred Hoiberg said he wanted to keep Parker in the second unit and would have liked him to close, but Hoiberg may feel differently after his squad was thumped on the road. Even if Parker isn't starting, the Bulls probably can't get away with playing Chandler Hutchison big minutes, so Parker should have some increased value for the next two weeks before Lauri Markkanen (elbow) comes back.

Justin Holiday scores five in 29 minutes: He didn't play in the fourth and he looks to be ticketed for a high-minute role with the Bulls being so thin. Holiday won't be getting the volume like he did last year before the Bulls shut him down, but he can hit treys, pick up some steals, he did play some four, and maybe he can get hot in the right matchup. He's not quite worth adding in shallower leagues, though.

Darius Miller will not return Friday: He was deemed questionable to return at the half, but was ruled out for the night a few minutes into the third quarter. Miller finished with three points, one rebound, two assists and a triple in four minutes. We could see more of Wes Johnson and Solomon Hill in the second half.
Jason Smith goes back to bench: With Ian Mahinmi (back) back in the starting lineup and the Wizards using a lot of small-ball lineups, there's a chance we don't see Smith at all tonight.

Ian Mahinmi (back) will start on Friday night: He went through shootaround after missing the last game. Mahinmi isn't likely to play big minutes in what should be an up-tempo game. If he's limited, there could be more minutes for Markieff Morris, Jason Smith, Kelly Oubre and Jeff Green.
Kenneth Faried out for Friday night: The team announced it in the first quarter, but Faried wasn't going to be in the rotation anyway.

Jalen Brunson getting the start for DSJ: Coach Rick Carlisle called Brunson a top-15 player in the draft, so his words match his actions here. Dennis Smith Jr. (ankle) could possibly miss more time, and Brunson has been solid in his time off the bench. He's only worth a flier in deep leagues for now.

Jimmy Butler will start on Friday night: There is a lot going on with Jimmy and the timing of his illness certainly raises some questions. Butler should have a lot of shots coming his way with Andrew Wiggins out of the lineup, or maybe Karl-Anthony Towns can get it going.

Andrew Wiggins (quad) will not play Friday: It'll be his second game out due to this injury and just the third of his career. It doesn't sound like Wiggins is going to miss time, but the Wolves aren't exactly in  their right state of mind. Josh Okogie will be getting another start and is set for big minutes.

J.J. Barea available to play vs. Raptors: He could be in the starting lineup after a mild hammy strain. If he's not starting, it could be Jalen Brunson with Dennis Smith Jr. (ankle) out for this one. JJB will be a popular DFS play.

Dennis Smith Jr. (ankle) will not play Friday: He played through an ankle tweak on Wednesday and was in visible pain after he rolled it. Smith Jr. was expected to play in this game, so hopefully it's just a precaution. This should give J.J. Barea more minutes while Wes Matthews and Luka Doncic should also benefit.
Dellavedova (forehead) likely to play: He has zero fantasy value right now with four total minutes on the season.

Luc Mbah a Moute (left knee) will not play: He was playing some five this week, so there could be a few more minutes available for the frontcourt guys. Montrezl Harrell went off against the Rockets on Sunday and is likely going to benefit most, but coach Doc Rivers said he likes playing Danilo Gallinari at the five.

Chris Paul back in the starting lineup: He has served his two-game suspension and should be ready for a huge role with James Harden (hamstring) out. CP3's usage rate and assist percentages have skyrocketed when Harden was on the bench in his time with Houston, so Paul has a massive upside tonight.

Jimmy Butler and Wiggins are game-time calls: The Wolves aren't the most transparent team and you have to wonder if the Wolves will hold Butler out for trade reasons. If Butler and Wiggins can't go, we're going to see a lot of Josh Okogie and Derrick Rose.
Michael Carter-Williams to the bench: Even with James Harden (hamstring) out tonight, Carter-Williams may not be asked to handle the ball much because Eric Gordon has played some point.

Carmelo Anthony will start on Friday vs. LAC: With James Harden (hamstring) and his 32.3 usage rate sitting this one out, Melo is basically a lock for double-digit shot attempts and will look to build off his 22-point game on Wednesday. We don't love his season-long outlook, but Melo should be in lineups tonight.

Deandre Ayton dealing with ankle soreness: This is likely just lingering effects from his ankle tweak last week. The Suns won't want this to be a problem all year, so maybe they opt to sit him even if it's minor. If he does sit Richaun Holmes would be a spot-start or DFS play.

Ryan Anderson is questionable for Saturday: He did have a hip issue in March, so this is something to watch. It feels like it's just a matter of time before Anderson losses minutes, so expect him to trend down. There should be plenty of minutes available for the Suns forwards and guards..

Dennis Smith Jr. expected to play Friday: He was playing with a limp in his previous outing after tweaking an ankle, but his status was never really in doubt. We were hoping to see DSJ improve his efficiency this season, but he's currently sitting at 37.5% from the field and 75% from the line with 2.8 turnovers. Things won't get any easier vs. Kyle Lowry.
